If so, what action did he take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

At that time I certainly did receive information stating the details of the original decision. Subsequently, I was advised that in August 1986 the General Manager approved, under declaration, an additional grant of $10,000 and that a bank loan guarantee for an additional $43,000 to enable the club to meet increased renovation costs was obtained. ANSWER.PARA: In addition, I was informed that the club was due to open in June and that the New South Wales region was investigating a request by the Woden Town Club for an additional guarantee of a $300,000 bank loan from the National Australia Bank to allow the purchase of 47 second-hand gaming machines and ancillary equipment from the City Club. At meeting No. 56 on 10 May 1988 commissioners approved that a decision on the Woden Town Club's application for an additional loan guarantee be made by the General Manager, under delegation, after consultation with the Chairman-the Chairman being Mrs McPherson. TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Housing and Aged Care inform the House of recent government initiatives to tackle the problems of homelessness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point about this question is that homelessness is usually a symptom of some other crisis in a person's life. That crisis can be related to unemployment, or more often than not to some personal crisis such as domestic violence, neglect, breakdown or illness. The Hawke Government recognises this when it introduced the supported accommodation assistance program (SAAP) along with the crisis accommodation program in 1984-85.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the Fraser Government did not have a coordinated program to cater for the most vulnerable sections of our community. In its last year in office it was only able to round up about $14m to spend on homelessness, compared with the $85m that we are spending this year. In other words, we are spending six times the amount that the Fraser Government spent when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer.

We have reviewed SAAP after the couple of years that it has been operating and we have built on the experiences of the Government and the community. We are now able to offer the States an extra $40m over the next three years on top of the record amount of money that is being spent this year. That means that about 150 new services will be available over the next three years and those will assist about another 15,000 people. That is what the Opposition spokesman on housing, the honourable member for Mayo, dares to describe as `cynical tokenism'. The emphasis of our new program is that we are trying to do away with the revolving door problem which is often a symptom of homelessness. We intend that this program should stabilise people's lives and help them to get back on their feet.

For the record, let me contrast the efforts of the two parties in government. Since we have been in government 220,000 households have been accommodated in public housing compared with 165,000 over the previous five years. As well 70,000 home loans have been provided to low income households compared with 50,000 under the former Government. Also, 70,000 additional rental dwellings have been provided since we have been in office compared with 40,000 over the previous five years. And that is before one starts talking about other issues and other record achievements of this Government in the field of employment. We have created more than one million new jobs and 60 per cent of those jobs have gone to women. Child-care, Medicare, pensions, rent assistance and Austudy are all issues which relate to homelessness. The reality is that the Opposition does not have any sustainable policy on housing, let alone homelessness.

Last week the honourable member for Mayo, the new frontbencher, had a unique opportunity to put his case to the Australian people in the pages of the Australian newspaper. He had his big opportunity to talk about the so-called housing crisis, what he perceived as the failure of the Government's policies and, more importantly, his own policies. What was the result? It is there for all of us to see: it was just like the election results-57 per cent of the people rejected his assertions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I remind you, Madam Speaker, of your own objection to former Speaker Snedden some time ago about Ministers addressing the matters of Opposition policy and not their own. The Minister has answered the question and he is now wasting the time of the Parliament when there are very significant issues before us. I would ask you, Madam Speaker, to request him to bring his answer to a close.
—The Minister will wind up.

—The issue is that 57 per cent of the people who responded to that poll at the request of the honourable member for Mayo rejected his policies and his assertions on the Government's policies. Even when he is the only player on the field he falls flat on his face in front of goal. I am not quite sure what the polo analogy would be in that regard, but I am sure there is one. The fact of the matter is that this Government is tackling homelessness across many portfolios. The key element of this is the supported accommodation assistance program. We have made our offer to the States and we hope it will be accepted.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. What were the reasons behind the decisions which saw Mr Charles Perkins being removed from his position as Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of background, I remind the House of comments I made in the House on both 1 November and 3 November. On 1 November I said, in relation to the Woden Town Club:

ANSWER.PARA: I am totally opposed to the club being given grant moneys. I would not give a poker machine club one cent of public money. I have told the ADC commissioners that.
On 3 November I said the following:

I think my position on the Woden Town Club is well and truly known. I should point out for the benefit of the House that the offer, and the documentation of the offer that has been alluded to in the media via the Senate Estimates Committee, has never formally been sent to that organisation. The offer has now been withdrawn and the matter will be reconsidered at the next meeting of the commissioners.

That is still the situation. It is important that the House understand the following details relating to the Woden Town Club: on 25 October the Woden Town Club was notified by fax that the club would be offered additional financial support from the ADC. The fax said the necessary documentation would be forthcoming. On 26 October Mr Andrew Jackomos, the Secretary of the Woden Town Club, told me this was the first day he had learned of this supposed offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —What date was that?

—It was 26 October. Mr Jackomos told me that this was the first day he had learned of this supposed offer, and he first learned of it when it was raised at a Senate Estimates committee on the same day. From this time until the morning of Friday, 4 November, I had been assured by both Mr Jackomos and Mr Perkins that no action had been taken by the club on this faxed document.

ANSWER.PARA: On 31 October, at the ADC meeting held at my request, with Mr Perkins present, I expressed my opposition to this funding proposal for the club to the commissioners. I then left the meeting, having stated my position. I have been informed that the ADC commissioners decided at that meeting to defer implementation of the previous funding decision and consider the matter again at the next meeting to be held in December. I am also informed that at the meeting the commissioners were informed that the Woden Town Club had not met to discuss the offer.

During last week and following that meeting of the ADC commissioners, I discussed the question of the funding arrangements by the ADC of the Woden Town Club with both the President of the club, Mr Perkins, and the Secretary of the club, Mr Jackomos. At no time during these discussions did Mr Perkins inform me that there had been a meeting of the Woden Town Club to discuss the matter of the funding.

On 3 November at approximately 5.40 p.m. my office received a phone call from an ADC officer to say that two board members of the Woden Town Club had delivered a letter to the ADC in Canberra, accepting the supposed offer of additional funding outlined in the faxed letter sent to the Secretary of the club on 25 October. At 10.15 p.m. on 3 November I finally managed to contact the Acting General Manager of the ADC, Mr Wyatt, and asked him for confirmation of the message I had received earlier that evening. He confirmed that the letter had been received and agreed to my request to bring a copy to my office the next morning. At no stage, until the afternoon of Thursday, 3 November, was there any hint that the Woden Town Club had met to consider the supposed offer of support, let alone respond in any positive way.

On 4 November at 8.45 a.m. Mr Wyatt brought a copy of the letter to my office. I have a copy here which I am happy to table and I do so now. The letter is from the Woden Town Club Secretary, Mr Jackomos, and its contents differed significantly from my belief of what had been arranged between the ADC and the club-a belief in no way challenged by Mr Jackomos or Mr Perkins at any time until the moment I met with Mr Perkins on 4 November. At 9 a.m. I had a meeting with the Prime Minister's Principal Private Secretary, to whom I gave a copy of the letter, and to whom I expressed my deepest reservations as to its implications. At 9.15 a.m. I met with Mr Perkins, confronting him with the letter and his statements about accepting an offer and demanding further assistance for the Woden Town Club. I told him that the letter posed enormous problems for our relationship. I regret to say that Mr Perkins, upon being told of my concern, did not offer any response other than to suggest withdrawing the letter. When I pointed out the improprieties of this idea, he suggested that another letter might be written.

Given these circumstances, I indicated to Mr Perkins that he should resign from his position as acting commissioner of the ADC. I also determined that I could no longer work with Mr Perkins as my Secretary and I left Mr Perkins in no doubt of my view. It had become clear to me that Mr Perkins was not prepared to give appropriate priority to his position as Secretary to the Department. I then left Mr Perkins in my office and proceeded to see the Prime Minister, to whom I put my case of not having a good enough basis for a working relationship with Mr Perkins.

It was clear that the contents of the letter from the club, of which Mr Perkins was the President, were inconsistent with what I was told by Mr Perkins as President of the club and Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I know now that Mr Perkins had discussed this matter with various people and, in particular, on Thursday, 3 November, at the Woden Town Club, because he told me so himself. Despite this, and knowing my strong views on the subject and my statement in Parliament, he had not informed me until this time, being the Friday. I judged that it was not plausible that Mr Perkins would not have known about the contents of a letter dated 3 November from the club to the Commission and referring to a meeting of the club on 27 October. He did not keep me fully informed as I could have reasonably expected on a matter of major current interest and about which he was in a unique position to know. Nor did I judge that Mr Perkins took adequate action which he was in a unique position to take to give effect to my clear position on a matter of the financial relationship between the Commission and the Woden Town Club. I just say this: Does anybody believe that a grant to enable a club to operate in this way has a priority over the needs of Aboriginal people? I stand by my commitment to that.

Following my meeting with Mr Perkins I left my office to speak with the Prime Minister and to report to him that because of this incident I could no longer have a good working relationship with Mr Perkins. Established administrative procedures then followed. The Prime Minister set in motion the necessary Public Service actions which led to Mr Perkins discussing his future prospects with the appropriate people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: Is Mr Andrew Jackomos, to whom he has just referred, still a member of his staff? If not, has he resigned, when and why? I understand that I will be receiving details of a job that he will be taking up, under the arrangements of the Public Service Commission, with another department, and I am seeking information on that.

—I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: In light of the constant stream of allegations made regarding matters in the administration of Aboriginal affairs, what will the Minister do to deal with these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has always been clear in its readiness to investigate fully allegations of maladministration or impropriety in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. There will be no cover-up. I wish to inform honourable members that the Government has established mechanisms and a process for investigating allegations which have been made. The allegations will be investigated in the first instance by the agencies appropriate to them as follows. The Auditor-General has already agreed to undertake a comprehensive audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission and will extend this as appropriate to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The Auditor-General is, of course, fully independent and has powers to conduct a wide-ranging investigation, particularly in areas of financial administration.

ANSWER.PARA: The Public Service Commissioner, who is also an independent statutory officer, will investigate those questions concerning personnel management in the Department. I might add that any staff classification issues will be investigated as is appropriate by the Department of Finance. In addition, the Government recognises that certain matters may still require further examination in light of these specialised investigations.

The Government has asked Mr Andrew Menzies, AM, OBE, the former Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, to make such inquiry if necessary. He has agreed. I emphasise that the judgment of which matters, if any, would warrant such further examination will be exercised independently by Mr Menzies. Together, these investigations will clearly be able to comprehend all the various allegations made in the report of the Senate Estimates Committee, including the minority part of that report. The approach would be sufficiently broad to pick up other allegations. On timing, I expect that these investigations will be completed in time to enable me to make a statement early in the new year.

The approach which I have described represents the best means by which an expeditious, thorough and cost-effective investigation can be conducted. There is no need for the more complex and costly process of a judicial inquiry. Some of the allegations which have been made-I repeat, they are allegations-may be relevant to the former Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I wish to make it clear that Mr Perkins will be given every opportunity to put his views on the allegations against him and against the administration of his Department. Pending the outcome, Mr Perkins is an unattached Secretary and is receiving the salary and allowances of his previous office.

—Can the Minister for Social Security explain to the House the steps taken by the Government to make sure that pensioner and beneficiary families are not trapped into dependency on social security and report to the House on the effects of these policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most important measure that the Government has taken to ensure that families are not trapped into dependency is the family allowance supplement, which, from December, will be paid at a maximum rate of $24 for younger children and $28 for teenage children. The payments are made on the basis of income, not on the basis of whether the claimant is receiving a pension or a benefit. The Economic Planning Advisory Council report, which has received some attention in the press this morning, made it clear that the family allowance supplement has worked in that regard, making it worth while for beneficiaries to work. The report says in passing that 95 per cent of families receiving the family allowance supplement would be more than 25 per cent worse off if they were to go onto unemployment benefit.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not the only measure that the Government has taken to reduce poverty traps for pensioners and beneficiaries. We have lifted the free areas for pension, benefit and income tests, which has enabled pensioners and beneficiaries to earn substantially more with no effect on their pensions. With respect to children of beneficiary families, we have doubled the free area from $6 to $12 per child per week. We introduced the earnings credit. As pensioners who have not been working get under that earnings credit arrangement, they keep the full pension for three or four weeks after commencing a job. With respect to sole parents and others receiving maintenance payments, we have introduced a separate income test, so that sole parents who get maintenance have the full benefit of the general free area for any earned income and continue to get child payments for four weeks after they commence work.

Quite clearly, we have built into those changes-particularly the changes with respect to the payment of the family allowance supplement, the arrangement of free areas, particularly the creation of a separate income test, and the introduction of an earnings credit-massive incentives for such people to work. For example, if a sole parent with two children who is solely reliant on a pension with $52 a week maintenance payment were to achieve a job and move from that pension at a rate of payment of around $360 a week, he or she would, in the initial period-in the first three weeks in the job-receive an additional $490 over and above the payment he or she would have received under the previous arrangements. On an ongoing basis those changes represent an increase in real income of something like $32 a week over and above the payment prior to the Government introducing the change with respect to the separate income test on maintenance. So there are quite massive incentives for sole parents and other beneficiaries to move into the work force.

In conclusion: I have remarked a number of times on the success the Government has had not only in terms of creating jobs but also in terms of reducing the numbers on unemployment benefit. I make the point that that, of course, impacts on families with dependent children. Since May 1987, when there were about 224,000 children in beneficiary families in which the principal members of the families were on unemployment benefit, we are now down, according to the latest figures, to 203,000 children in beneficiary families. So there has been a reduction of about 10 per cent, or 20,000 children, because families now have employed adults. It is the kinds of changes that the Government has made with respect to income tests that provide that very positive incentive for such families to move from dependence on benefits to the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the claim by the former Secretary of the New South Wales Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Ms Pat O'Shane, that she had personally provided the Minister with a list of names and organisations involved in departmental patronage and maladministration. When did Ms O'Shane provide that information to the Minister? What were the details of that information? Was the information available to him or to the Prime Minister prior to their initial expressions of confidence in Mr Perkins's management of his Department last week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ms O'Shane made a statement on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The next morning I contacted her workplace in the Magistrates Court in Sydney. She was unavailable to talk to me. A series of phone calls were made subsequent to that during the day. On each occasion she rang me when I was in Question Time and when I got back to her she was back in court. After, I think, two more days we did have a discussion on the phone. When she rang back my office, she left with my office some information regarding certain issues.

—Order!
—Are you saying what she said on the radio is untrue?
—Order! Honourable members will cease interjecting. The Minister is answering the question. The Minister will continue.

—Order! The right honourable member will not argue with the Chair.
—It is extraordinary that a question is asked--

—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. My understanding is that it is inappropriate in this place for any offensive remark to be made of a member of the judiciary. Ms O'Shane is a magistrate. —If he is alleging that she lied on radio, he should do it by resolution.

—Madam Speaker, at no time would I question the integrity of Ms Pat O'Shane, nor have I ever-never. Ms O'Shane raised with me a series of points. We had a lengthy discussion about those matters. ANSWER.PARA: There are accusations and they will properly be addressed. I repeat to the House: it matters not to me who it is; if there is some form of corruption, misappropriation of funds or some other matter that somebody raises, either in this chamber or in public, my commitment to fix that is still the same as it was when I first took over this job. I resent the right honourable member for New England implying that I made a derogatory comment about Ms O'Shane. I did not. I resent that. It is grossly unfair of the right honourable member to say that, because it is not true. Ms O'Shane contacted me and I have acted on the contact.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Can the Minister inform the House of any progress in her initiatives to commercialise the inventions of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McEwen for his question and I am happy to report that, following the restructuring of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, we are now able to take maximum advantage of its intellectual property with a view to maximising its commercial potential-without, I must add, undermining its first responsibility to the Australian Defence Force. Recently, I signed a licensing agreement between the Aeronautical Research Laboratory, which is one of the laboratories of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, and Schlumberger Instrumentation Australia (SIA). That will allow SIA to develop what we call Austower, which is an air traffic control trainer which will be based at the Royal Australian Air Force base in East Sale. Once it is developed for East Sale it will then be able to be developed for export. I think that is the key to the developments in the DSTO. On the one hand we want to provide better facilities for defence, as is being done with the Austower development, and on the other we want to have them available for their export potential.

ANSWER.PARA: Austower simulates a full-scale control tower overlooking an aerodrome scene of up to 10 aircraft and ground vehicle activities. It can also simulate varied conditions of visibility, various kinds of landings and take-offs and even emergency situations. It is a great example of the high level of technology available in the DSTO which must be put to the good use of defence but which also must be used for its export potential. I want to thank everyone involved in the DSTO for that product. I hope this project will be the first of many successful commercial projects.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Given the importance of Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea and the joint declaration of principles signed by Prime Minister Hawke and former Prime Minister Wingti, can the Minister advise the House of the outcome of his recent discussions with Ministers in the Papua New Guinea Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the comments that have been raised about this matter go to the issues relating to the Papua New Guinea-Indonesia border. Quite properly, those matters are bilateral matters between Papua New Guinea and Indonesia and I would not seek to comment on them. However, the meeting afforded an opportunity to go into further detail about our very extensive defence cooperation program with Papua New Guinea and specific matters were raised there that are of direct interest to the Papua New Guineans. One of those goes to the air mobility of their ground forces. They have put forward propositions to us, under the defence cooperation program, to assist in the development of their air wing with the provision of support for helicopters. We have indicated support in principle for that and we will go into discussions with them about it.

ANSWER.PARA: We also took further discussions that we have been having for some 18 months on the question of engineering projects, one of which related to the development of roads in the border area by the employment of engineering elements to Vanimo to operate in a joint project with the Papua New Guinea defence forces. The Papua New Guinea officials indicated to us that they found a suggestion that we increase the number of patrol boats for them from four to six acceptable. They were appreciative of that and indicated to us that proposals we put forward for the development of Manus Island were also acceptable. All in all, the meeting was very useful in cementing the process set in place by the joint declaration of principles, particularly that element that implies a commitment to building a substantial Papua New Guinean defence capability. —Can the Minister for Housing and Aged Care inform the House what impact administration of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is having on rural pharmacies and, in particular, on pharmacies in less populated areas of Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Brand for her question. I presume she has been attracted to this matter by the issues raised by the Leader of the National Party in Western Australia and the Pharmacy Guild of Western Australia among others. In that regard this Government has no policy to close small rural pharmacies. The Government recognises the important role of country pharmacies, particularly in the delivery of health and to the community itself. We can safely discount the claims made by the National Party Leader as rubbish. The claims by the Pharmacy Guild that Government policies are forcing pharmacy closures are simply not supported by the facts. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) has risen by more than $330m in the past three years. For that, pharmacies get about 40c of every PBS dollar. From the mark-ups and fees on national health service (NHS) prescriptions it is estimated that pharmacy income has risen by more than 30 per cent in the past three years due to the increased prescribing of expensive drugs in large quantities.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that we will soon see information, not from the Government but from other sources, that will certainly show vast increases in profit in pharmacies in the last couple of years, particularly in relation to country pharmacies. The pharmacy remuneration is not determined by the Government, it is determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, which is an independent body whose determinations are binding on the Government and pharmacists. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Menzies moving forthwith:
That this House is of the opinion that:

(1) A Royal Commission should be established to inquire into: (a) the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and the Aboriginal Development Commission and all other Commonwealth agencies and corporations responsible for the administration of Aboriginal Affairs; and (b) the administration of the office of Minister for Aboriginal Affairs by the current Minister and by the current Minister for the Arts and Territories; and
(2) The Royal Commission should take evidence and conduct its proceedings in public.
Will the Government accept the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—The Government will not accept it. We have, therefore, at the beginning of the debate on this motion, a very clear indicator of the hypocrisy of the Government. During Question Time we heard the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) say, `There will be no cover-up; it will all come out. There will be an opportunity for people to answer any question that is raised'. Since then, only a few minutes ago, two things have occurred: the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has said, `No, I won't table the document from which I am reading'-a document with regard to the proposed inquiry that he wants to establish-and the Government is now taking a technical and specious objection to prevent debate on this most important matter of public interest and concern. We say that Standing and Sessional Orders should be set aside so that a motion can be put forward to establish a royal commission into these matters of very great concern relating to the public administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In this country, unfortunately, there is now a smell of appallingly bad administration hanging over Aboriginal affairs. As a result of recent allegations made, there are now suggestions of corruption going to the highest levels of the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country. Further, we say it is a clear case in which two Ministers should very promptly be brought to account for their administration of the office of Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

The Government adopted the tactic today of saying, `Well, let's get in first. We think the Opposition might move this motion, so let's get in first and let's try to give the impression that we really are on the ball and that we really are prepared to have an investigation'. What was the Government's response? It said, `The Auditor-General is already all fired up. We will let him go beyond the review of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and also review the Department of Aboriginal Affairs itself'. So grudgingly, and only because the Opposition has pushed the matter, the Auditor-General is now to look at the Department.

The other thing that the Government has done is to say, `We will have an inquiry. We will get Mr Andrew Menzies-good man that he is-to investigate all these allegations'. The Opposition says that an inquiry by Mr Andrew Menzies-good man though he is-is not good enough. We say that only a royal commission, with all its powers, can get to the bottom of this matter. A royal commission can demand witnesses to appear before it. Witnesses who give evidence before it have some protection with regard to defamation, which is exactly what Mr Gary Foley said this morning when he made a clear allegation of cover-up against the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding). Mr Gary Foley said, `I am not going to come forward to some inquiry or see the Minister. I want some protection for the allegations that I have to make'. The Government is running for cover. The Government is clearly engaged in a complete cover-up, from top to the bottom, in all of these matters.

We say that it is a clear case in which Standing and Sessional Orders should be set aside and a clear case for the establishment of a royal commission. That is so for those reasons. Over the last few weeks, there has been a whole series of allegations concerning bad administration in the Aboriginal Development Commission. I do not have time, of course, to go into it all in detail. Honourable members will be aware of the matter concerning the Woden Town Club, the poker machines and the large amount of money spent in that area. Honourable members will be aware of the involvement of the Minister in that and the fact that he had his own ministerial staff involved in the matter. How can this not be a case for an inquiry? How can this not be a case for a royal commission when the Minister's own secretary is involved as one of the parties in this particular deal? Honourable members will aware of that incident. They will be aware of the matters revealed in the Senate inquiry into the Oasis Hotel in Walgett and the expenditure of public money on that. We are all aware that, with respect to both that and the agricultural property at Nardoola, it would appear on the surface that what has happened is that the Aboriginal Development Commission gave away property, property bought with taxpayers' money. A very valuable property was simply given away irresponsibly and in such a way that if ever there were a case for a royal commission or inquiry this must be it.

It is abundantly clear that events since the Senate committee inquiry have made an even stronger case than ever before for having a royal commission with the powers of a royal commission. What has happened since then? In the first place we have had further allegations. Secondly, we have had the Minister actually sack the Secretary to his Depart- ment. Thirdly, we have had the appalling spectacle that we have seen here today of the Minister passing the buck to the Secretary and putting the blame on the Secretary. We have seen that, and if ever there were a case for investigation this surely must be it. We have reached a state of affairs in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs where there is a clear evidence of bad administration, suggestions-at least on some evidence-of corruption and absolute chaos reigning within the administration of the portfolio by the Minister and the Minister actually being driven to the point of sacking his permanent head. On top of that we have the permanent head saying, `The Minister knew all about it'. That is what Mr Perkins said. He said that the Minister knew everything that was involved in the portfolio. And then, as if that were not enough to justify an inquiry, at the end of the day in Question Time today what do we find but the Minister pouring a bucket on Mr Perkins and putting the blame on him. Not only is that a discreditable form of conduct: it is one that must surely add to public concern; it is one that must surely make out even more strongly a case for a wide-ranging inquiry with the powers of a royal commission-powers which Mr Andrew Menzies does not have-into this whole sorry scandal.

One of the reasons that agitate the public and agitate us about this matter is the involvement of Ministers. Here we have what would seem to be on the surface, at the very least, a clear case of bad administration by two Ministers, a clear case of two Ministers not living up to their ministerial responsibilities. If we need any guidance for what our attitude should be on this we need to go no further than what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said only a few days ago in his Sir Robert Garran Oration. In his Garran lecture a couple of days ago the Prime Minister told us this about ministerial responsibility: `You know, the problem is that Oppositions too often are all too eager to cry leg before wicket'. This is not a case of leg before wicket. This is a case of two Ministers, the Department and the Government being clean bowled-and clean bowled for a duck. If there were ever a case that called out for an inquiry with real powers and not just a superficial inquiry this must surely be it.

We have all of the ingredients which justify a royal commission. We have bad administration, cover-ups, slack ministerial performance and an attempt at the end of the day to put the blame onto the former Secretary to the Department. We will not be satisfied with anything other than a royal commission with the powers of a royal commission, because it is only that which will get to the bottom of this sordid, smelly deal which has now involved the Minister for the Arts and Territories with the allegations made against him--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I am sure that every member on this side of the House would second it. Every member on the other side of the House should second it. SPEECH.PARA: This motion is not just about Aboriginal affairs. It is not just about how the current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and the previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding)-he is the only one who still has the courage to be in the chamber-have run their portfolios; it is about standards of government administration. It is about a betrayal-a betrayal of trust that was put in this Government by Aboriginal Australians, a betrayal of the trust that we all have as members of this place to look after those people on behalf of whom we have the responsibility of administering government policy.

What we hear in this place today are selective revelations about the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). We have been told today what the Government is prepared to tell us. The Minister said in this place, `I have a personal commitment to ensuring that every allegation made, every suggestion of corruption, will be investigated'. Let me say that it has gone well beyond that. It is too late for the Minister to say, `I will do this behind closed doors'. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) knows it. That is why he has refused to agree to this motion today. It has gone far beyond a private, closed door inquiry. The only way that this matter can be dealt with now is by having a public inquiry, a judicial inquiry, a royal commission, where the whole issue comes out and the light of day goes into the dark crannies of this Government's administration.

Everybody knows that there is something wrong within the Department. Everyone knows that this Government has a commitment to covering it up. Last week in this place the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, `There will be no cover-up' and then proceeded to stonewall. When the issue would not go away, he probably got together with a few of the right wing policy advisers and they said, `You had better throw someone overboard'. So, what happened? Mr Perkins went overboard. Now what are we doing today, in this place? There are protests by the Government that there is no cover-up and commitments to have an investigation, but there is a total stonewall.

The Minister came in here today and announced that the Government was going to have some sort of inquiry. He referred to the inquiries as `two vehicles', not as inquiries. I asked him to table the document from which he was obviously reading. What did he say? He said, `No, it is confidential'. That is the approach the Government has taken to this whole issue-`It is confidential unless we are prepared to let it go and we will not let it go if it is going to cause us any embarrassment'. It is obvious to Blind Freddy that this whole issue is capable of embarrassing the entire Government. It goes well beyond this Department. It goes well beyond the ADC. It goes well beyond Charles Perkins. It goes well beyond Clyde Holding. It goes to the very standards of ministerial propriety and the sort of government this Prime Minister runs. He is not even prepared to come into the chamber and debate this issue. The Minister himself has gone. The only person who is sitting here listening-well might he do so because he knows what his role in this whole issue was-is Clyde Holding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not facilitate this motion or the nonsense of the arguments that are associated with it. I will take seriatim a few of the arguments that were raised. In the course of the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) in particular, certain aspersions were cast upon the former Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs which cannot pass in this place without an answer. SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for Mr Perkins being placed on the unattached list were made quite clear by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who evaded nothing in his answers to questions that were put to him by the Opposition today. The reasons relate quite specifically to the advice given the Minister during last week about Mr Perkins's knowledge of the events surrounding a decision by the Woden Town Club to accept an offer which had been withdrawn from the Aboriginal Development Commission. That is all. It related specifically to the type of advice that a Secretary ought to be providing his Minister. A totally reasonable position was reached by the Minister that in those circumstances he could not continue to work with Mr Perkins. That was all. We must not let stand in this place effectively an imputation or an allegation by the Opposition that Mr Perkins's services to the Aboriginal Affairs Department were terminated for any other reason at all. That goes to the sort of exaggeration that members of the Opposition have brought to this discussion, an exaggeration which leads them to the nonsensical position that the normal processes of investigation of departmental affairs by the Commonwealth ought to be overthrown in this instance, and a royal commission created.

Why do we have an Auditor-General's Office if it is not to investigate claims that the expenditure of public funds has been misapplied? Why does the Opposition assume that an Auditor-General who has not declared himself to have the incapacity to investigate those matters ought not to investigate them? That is patently absurd. All the matters that have been raised, and the only matters that were mentioned by the honourable member for Menzies as he proposed his motion, were matters that had gone to the Senate Estimates committee and subsequently an indication was given by the committee, as I understand it, that these matters would be considered by the Auditor-General. He brought out nothing more. There were no additional suggestions to those materials that had already been handed over to or discussed in the Senate. There were no additional reasons why there was some especially unique case of corruption here that required anything other than a normal investigation by the Auditor-General's Office. We do have these proper processes in the Commonwealth. These processes stand outside the occasional efforts by the Opposition to take benefit from that.

Nothing that has been alleged so far is in any shape or form an equivalent-a moral, financial, ethical, political or legal equivalent-of the circumstances that have that royal commission operating into that criminal conspiracy that seems to have been the government of Queensland in the course of the last few years. It goes specifically to whether or not-and I am only going on the statements of the honourable member for Menzies here and those that have been made by other Liberals-public funds have been appropriately expended. There is a department which is devoted to such matters. There have been other allegations and those go to whether or not in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs there has been evidence of nepotism in the promotion and appointment of individuals. Those matters are reasonable for investigation, but there is a process in the Public Service for those matters to be properly investigated and that is by the Public Service Commissioner.

In the 70- or 80-odd years that we have been developing public policy and public authority in this country we have created the appropriate procedures for those sorts of investigations. To go for a further investigation outside this framework of the appropriate procedures established over time since Federation requires far more dramatic, sinister and dangerous allegations than any of those that have been made by the honourable member for Menzies in his speech to his motion, by any of the questioning by the Opposition in the Senate Committee and by any of the suggestions that have been made public.

Sensible administration of public policy demands that the Government does exactly what the Government has done in this regard: refer matters to the Auditor-General for report; and refer matters to the Public Service Commissioner for report. There is a possibility that in the course of that there might be an area in which the Auditor-General or the Public Service Commissioner might want additional advice. We have said in those circumstances that Mr Andrew Menzies, who has quite rightly been detailed by the honourable member for Menzies as a person who is in this regard totally above reproach and who has the complete capacity to comprehend the processes of bureaucracy, will take the inquiry further if such an inquiry is necessary arising from the matters that have been advised by the Auditor-General.

We have proper procedures in this country for appropriate problems. It is only when those problems get to an extraordinary extent that we move outside those proper procedures, such as when an entire police force, or a substantial portion of it, appears to have become corrupt. There is no suggestion in any of this that we have the situation where the wives of senior public officials are standing on street corners receiving funds from the criminal element of our community in order to pay off politicians and the like. We have no allegations in these particular matters, and we need to get some balance in this discussion, of Premiers of States directing police against their political opponents.

What we possibly have in these circumstances-and this is to be demonstrated-is roughly the moral equivalent of the behaviour of those members of the Liberal Party of Australia who accepted, from funders of their campaigns in the course of their activities in New South Wales, cars; or something of the immoral equivalent of members of the Liberal Party who misused the processes by which public funds are declared in the course of election campaigns in New South Wales. That is basically where we are at. Of course there is no Auditor-General's Department or process to investigate those positions. We rely on the statements of the Premier or anyone else in New South Wales about how they propose to handle that matter. In that regard we do not have and nor does New South Wales, an Auditor-General's process to go through that, so some other means of inquiry into that might sensibly be established. Honourable members opposite who are so anxious that there should be public inquiries into these matters might ask Mr Greiner whether he proposes to do anything about it. I am absolutely certain, after the events of the weekend, that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) would be perfectly prepared to invite Mr Greiner to discuss the matter because after all the Leader of the Opposition, who has been enormously subdued in this place over the last two weeks, was given over that weekend something more to be subdued about by Mr Greiner's handling of those matters.

The Government has detailed a totally appropriate means of handling these allegations. No allegation has been suggested or made that would mean that the Auditor-General or the Public Service Commissioner could not proceed with them. But if such were to emerge we have set in place a totally appropriate mechanism for handling that. The Opposition's position on this is entirely specious. The Opposition position on this has quite reasonably been rejected by the Government. The Opposition's position on this is totally inappropriate to the nature of the allegations made, to the nature of the charges made. As I said, it is in no way the moral, economic, political, or judicial equivalent of the sorts of problems created by Opposition parties in Queensland.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPANSION OF INTERNATIONAL TERMINAL COMPLEX, SYDNEY (KINGSFORD-SMITH) AIRPORT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the thirteenth report of the Committee for 1988, relating to the expansion of the international terminal complex at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report which I have just tabled relates to the approval by the Public Works Committee of the expansion of the international terminal complex at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport at an estimated cost of $214m at April 1988 prices. The Committee considers the need for these works to be urgent. When the inadequacies of the existing international terminal complex are combined with the projected growth in international passenger numbers of at least 7 per cent per annum into the medium term future, it is clear that the Government must act now to expand existing international terminal facilities. Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is a critical facility for international tourism, business activity and cargo for Sydney, New South Wales and the Australian economy. Any inadequacies at the airport will have significant ramifications for Australia's economic prosperity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee supports the Federal Airports Corporation's decision to fast-track the development. As a further means of ensuring the project is completed on time, on cost and with the objective of eliminating industrial disputation, the Committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation encourage the development of an industrial agreement between the successful construction contractor and the unions. Due to the complexity of the proposed international terminal development, a significant component of the facilities and related infrastructure will be contributed by other organisations, namely, the airlines, Commonwealth Government bodies such as, Customs, health, immigration and police, oil companies and the New South Wales Government. The Committee noted the project is supported strongly by all of those groups, each of which has agreed to provide its respective facilities or infrastructures.

In considering the proposal the Committee also gave careful consideration to the concerns of the residents and councils which had raised a number of objections to the proposal, particularly in relation to the Federal Airports Corporation's environmental assessment. While not questioning the quality of that assessment, the Committee shares the view of the residents and councils that the Federal Airports Corporation would have been better advised to have secured the services of an independent environmental expert to prepare the assessment of environmental issues.

In conclusion, the Committee has noted the work which the Federal Airports Corporation has commissioned on the development of a master plan for the international sector of the airport. To ensure the overall orderly development and operation of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport the Committee has recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation prepare a master plan for the whole of the airport as expeditiously as possible.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Government came to office committed to transforming the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) into an effective instrument of industry policy after the previous Government had left the Corporation to languish. AIDC was moved to the industry portfolio and in late 1983 the AIDC Act was amended to expand the role of the Corporation. The amendments enabled it to provide finance for the restructuring and revitalisation of industry and for high technology and other growth industries in order to improve the international competitiveness of Australian industry.

AIDC responded well, the focus of its investment activities altered significantly, the Corporation engaged in an intense process of self-examination and emerged revitalised and reorganised with the Board and staff determined to make a significant contribution to the Government's industry policy objectives. AIDC's ability to provide both loan and equity capital across the spectrum of new and old industries is a key characteristic which differentiates it from other financial institutions. AIDC is now making a solid contribution not only in its day to day business activities but also to the heavy engineering plan, raw materials processing under the textiles, clothing and footwear package and the anti-malaria joint venture.

As a consequence, the Corporation has experienced a period of very strong asset growth of over 250 per cent in the four years to 30 June 1987. However, its capital base has emerged as a factor that could jeopardise AIDC's future contribution to industry development, especially in terms of its equity investment program, which is essential if it is to make its full contribution to industry policy objectives. At present, AIDC has paid up capital of $100m and $93.6m in accumulated reserves. However, budgetary circumstances have ensured that additional capital contributions have been the exception rather than the rule. A provision introduced in 1983 requiring the Corporation to pay a dividend of 50 per cent of net profit after tax has also slowed the growth of reserves. In line with prudent commercial practice, AIDC apportions capital to the various components of its business, appropriate to the risk-return profile of each class of business. This is essential in order to maintain AIDC's credit standing. However, this places a constraint on the level of capital intensive equity investments, although they are highly desirable from a policy viewpoint.

Confronted with the capital problem the Government examined a number of options: firstly, to continue as at present; secondly, to provide a substantial capital instalment from the Budget; or, thirdly, to raise equity capital from the private sector. In evaluating these options it was important to maintain AIDC as an effective financial instrument of industry policy. For this reason the first option was unacceptable. It would have undermined the progress achieved by AIDC over the last five years, returning it to the situation it confronted before this Government came to office. It would also have had a disastrous impact on the morale of the Corporation and its ability to retain key staff. AIDC's loan portfolio would have soon ceased to grow and the investment strategy would increasingly have been determined by the need for short term profitability. New investment in the more innovative and useful areas, particularly equity investments, would have had to be abandoned.

Given the public interest roles expected of AIDC, which remain the raison d'etre for its continued presence in the public sector, it would be preferable if the whole of the required capital could be found from the Budget-the second option. However, the budgetary realities facing the Government inevitably mean that the Government would not have been able to provide the capital required.

The third option involving raising capital from the private sector could have been implemented in a number of ways. Capital could have been raised in the Corporation itself either by issuing voting or non-voting shares. A listed unit trust holding non-voting shares in the Corporation could have also been established. However, these approaches would have either raised insufficient capital or would have altered the essential focus of AIDC's activities. The Government therefore has decided to allow AIDC to establish a listed subsidiary company to conduct most of its loan and investment business with up to 30 per cent of the equity to be offered to the public. It is expected that initially up to 20 per cent of equity will be offered for some $50m.

AIDC remains a statutory corporation 100 per cent owned by the Commonwealth. The Corporation will retain its developmental charter and continue to be subject to general policy guidance from the Government. The subsidiary's objectives will also be directed towards and will cover AIDC's statutory charter. Directors of AIDC will compose the majority of the subsidiary's board. Under the reorganisation the bulk of the business of the Corporation will be transferred to the new wholly owned subsidiary.

Assets and liabilities associated with the national interest activities of AIDC will remain with the Corporation. It is intended that AIDC will also remain as the borrower for the group. In return for the transfer of assets and liabilities the subsidiary will issue shares to the Corporation. The subsidiary will then at a time determined by market conditions issue shares to the public and be listed.

The transfer of the assets and liabilities is to be tax revenue neutral. No tax or stamp duty, State or Commonwealth, is to be paid in respect of the transfer. The subsidiary is also to be placed in the same tax position as the Corporation in respect of the transferred assets and liabilities. It would be inappropriate for any taxes or charges to be levied in respect of the transfer, given that the activities of the subsidiary will be those previously carried out by AIDC. In any event the cost in terms of taxes and charges normally associated with such a transfer would have been so large as to defeat the whole purpose of the reorganisation.

Throughout the reorganisation and the raising of share capital from the public appropriate ministerial control will be maintained. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce will, against criteria set out in the Bill, nominate the subsidiary to which the Corporation will transfer its business; specify the assets, instruments and liabilities not being transferred, all other assets, instruments and liabilities being transferred to the subsidiary; fix the day the reorganisation takes place; determine the net value of the transferred business; determine the total nominal value of shares issued to the Corporation; and have the power to issue directions in relation to the first share issue to the public. The market will determine the price of the shares for any subsequent issues. The rights of those staff members transferring from AIDC to the subsidiary have been fully protected under this Bill.

The establishment of the listed subsidiary should not be construed as a partial privatisation of AIDC but rather as an opportunity for the public to share in the national development objectives of AIDC. No Commonwealth assets will be sold off and the Corporation will remain 100 per cent owned by the Commonwealth. No single private person or associated group will be permitted to hold more than 10 per cent of the subsidiary's voting equity. This condition and others will ensure the continuing effectiveness of AIDC and the subsidiary in meeting industry policy objectives. These objectives will remain unchanged as will the strict commercial approach to its business that has been a hallmark of the Corporation over past years.

In contrast to privatisation measures in Britain, the additional capital raised from the public by the subsidiary will remain with, and contribute directly to, the growth and financial performance of the AIDC group and not flow to Consolidated Revenue. To further assist AIDC the Government has also decided to forgo the 1987-88 dividend which would normally be due to be paid by 31 December 1988.

The Bill also amends the mechanism by which future dividend payments to the Commonwealth will be determined, bringing AIDC into line with other government business enterprises. Instead of paying 50 per cent of net profit after tax each year AIDC will recommend a dividend to the Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce who may approve the recommendation or direct the Corporation to pay a higher or lower dividend. Similarly, the remuneration of AIDC's Chief Executive will be determined by the Board in consultation with the Remuneration Tribunal. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce will also now appoint the Chief Executive of the Corporation on the recommendation of the Board.

The Bill increases the capital payable to the Corporation from $150m to $200m, of which $100m has been paid up. The forgone 1987-88 dividend will be counted towards the paid in capital of the Corporation. The unpaid capital will be available, subject to appropriation, to enable the Corporation to discharge its obligations. However, it is intended to be available only if the Corporation has exhausted all other options in discharging its obligations.

The Bill also contains other consequential and minor amendments that will assist both AIDC and the subsidiary in performing their functions. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Moore) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an omnibus Bill proposing miscellaneous amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. The main proposals contained in the Bill are, firstly, to amend the manner in which the quantity of beer produced is measured for the purposes of assessing both customs and excise duty-clauses 10 and 33; secondly, to amend the controls pertaining to prohibited exports, so as to permit the Minister for Defence to suspend licences and permissions to export goods from Australia in circumstances where it is in Australia's national interest to suspend such licences or permissions-clause 8; thirdly, to extend the duty free entry to the Australian mainland of goods from Christmas Island to those goods which were 50 per cent produced on the Island-clause 11; fourthly, to amend offence provisions contained in sections 228 and 234 of the Customs Act 1901-clauses 20 and 23; and, fifthly, to provide, as part of the Government's decision to impose for the first time excise duties on government instrumentalities, that existing legislative provisions protecting those instrumentalities from excise duty are of no effect-paragraph 29 (b) and clause 30. In addition, the Bill makes a number of other minor, technical amendments to the Customs Act 1901, the Excise Act 1901 and the Off-Shore Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1982. These amendments are set out in detail in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.

I shall now outline the major proposals in the Bill. Clauses 10 and 33 amend the manner in which beer is measured for the purposes of assessing duty. The dutiable content of bulk vessels containing beer is presently fixed by legislation. For example, the traditional `kilderkin' is a vessel with a capacity of between 76.5 and 82 litres, although the dutiable contents is set at 79 litres irrespective of the vessel's actual contents.

Technological improvements in the manner in which bulk vessels are manufactured and filled means that it is now possible to measure beer more accurately. As from 1 February 1989, it is proposed to assess duty on bulk containers, that is, vessels in excess of two litres capacity, according to the quantity of beer nominated by the manufacturer as being in the bulk container providing that the actual contents do not exceed 101.5 per cent of the nominated quantity of the beer. As from 1 July 1991, the 1.5 per cent overfill tolerance just discussed will be reduced to one per cent.

For beer in bottles and cans up to two litre capacity that are entered for home consumption as from 1 February 1989, duty will be based on the labelled contents of the container providing the actual contents do not exceed 101.5 per cent of the labelled contents of the container.

I turn now to clause 8 of the Bill, which allows for the Minister for Defence to suspend previously granted licences or permissions to export goods from Australia in circumstances where it is in Australia's national interest to do so. The Government announced in June this year that the existing export controls on defence related goods would be revised so as to reduce constraints on exports where that could be done without prejudice to Australia's national interests and international obligations.

The existing controls require case by case ministerial permission for defence exports regardless of lethality or military significance. Case by case ministerial permission is also currently required for the export of non-military but potentially lethal goods like sporting firearms or commercial explosives.

The Government proposes introducing a system of licences for recognised exporters of potentially lethal, non-military goods. This system, whilst enabling the Government to stop exports of such goods in particular circumstances, will eliminate the current requirement for case by case approval of all such exports. When circumstances require, authorised exporters will be notified that export of these goods to particular destinations will require ministerial approval on a case by case basis. Case by case ministerial approval will still be required by non-authorised exporters of such goods.

Although the Government wishes to remove impediments to this trade, it recognises that from time to time circumstances may arise which make it contrary to Australia's national interest to continue exports to particular destinations. This proposed amendment to the Customs Act makes it clear that the Government may impose these controls should the circumstances arise.

Clause 11 provides for an extension of duty free entry to the Australian mainland for goods imported from the external Territory of Christmas Island. Currently, provision is made for the duty free entry into Australia of goods from the Territory where those goods are the produce of manufacture of the Territory, unless similar goods produced or manufactured in Australia are subject to excise duties. To meet the existing requirements of the Customs Act 1901 that deem goods to be the `produce or manufacture' of Christmas Island, those goods must either be wholly manufactured in the Territory or partly manufactured, where the last process of their manufacture was performed on Christmas Island and not less than 75 per cent of their factory or work cost is represented by the value of labour and/or material of Christmas Island or Australia.

However, as part of the Government's strategy to foster the development of new manufacturing industries on Christmas Island, in the face of an uncertain future for the phosphate mining industry, it is proposed from 1 January 1989 to reduce the local Australian content requirement under the Customs Act from 75 per cent to 50 per cent. This is the same preferential treatment currently applying to Forum island countries and Papua New Guinea.

It is hoped that this matter will encourage small industries that will generate local employment and income. The Government considers this measure to be highly desirable in view of the small size of the population, its remoteness from the Australian mainland and its historical dependence on one industry, namely phosphate mining. This measure is consistent with the Government's policy on Christmas Island, namely, to widen and diversify the island's economic base and improve its financial and management arrangements.

Clause 20 amends the offence contained in section 228 of the Customs Act 1901. This section currently provides for the forfeiture to the Crown of ships or boats not exceeding 250 tons registered tonnage where that ship or boat has been used in smuggling, or knowingly used in unlawful importations or exportations, or is found to be altered so as to allow for the concealment of goods; or where the master of the ship has refused permission for Customs to search the ship, or cannot account for cargo deficiencies.

The Government has decided that references to `registered tonnage' should be replaced with references to the `overall length' of a ship, because the maritime term `registered tonnage' is ambiguous, having a number of possible meanings. It is now proposed to move to a basis of the `overall length' of the vessel by adopting the definition of the term contained in section 10 of the Shipping Registration Act 1981.

The length of 80 metres has been chosen as the appropriate qualifying measure as it is considered that the master of a ship or boat should be able to exercise sufficient control over a ship or boat not exceeding 80 metres in overall length to warrant forfeiture if one of the circumstances set out in section 228 is established. The owners of ships over 250 tons registered tonnage which have been engaged in the practices described above are currently subject to a penalty not exceeding $10,000. This penalty has remained the same for many years, and it is light compared with the replacement cost to an owner of a vessel under 80 metres overall length which is forfeited to the Crown. The Bill will increase the penalty for vessels over 80 metres overall length, and engaged in the activities I have mentioned, to $100,000.

Finally, clauses 29 and 30 of the Bill particularly implement a Government decision to impose excise liability on government business enterprises (GBEs) by removing any statutory exemptions from paying excise duty as from 1 July 1989. This complements amendments to the excise tariff proposed in the Excise Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, currently before this House, which contains the substantive provisions giving effect to this decision.

Most Commonwealth enterprises, particularly those in direct competition with the private sector, are subject to the full range of Commonwealth, State and local government taxes and charges. Consistent with the move to place Commonwealth business enterprises on a more commercial footing, the Government has decided that all GBEs should be exposed to the same charges as private businesses.

Accordingly, as was announced in the 25 May 1988 economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), excise duty will be payable by all GBEs, the only exemptions being those authorities that have express exemptions to pay excise duty inserted in their establishing legislation as from 1 July 1989.
Financial Impact Statement

The change in the manner in which beer is measured for the purposes of assessing duty is not intended to net the Government any more revenue. If necessary, duty rates on beer may be adjusted for an overall, industry-wide revenue neutral result. The revenue impact of extending duty free concessions to Christmas Island is difficult to assess, as much depends on the level of exports coming from the island. However, it is anticipated that the extension of the concession will only lead to a minimal loss of Government revenues.
The remaining amendments to the Acts have no direct financial impact. I commend the Bill to the House, and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
