Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988, which is now before the House, contains in its seven schedules a wide variety of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987-and that is an understatement. I shall briefly outline those amendments. Unfortunately, because the Bill contains 488 pages, I shall not be able to give the length of detail that many honourable members would want.

Schedule 2 to the Bill, operative on and from 1 January 1988, contains amendments necessary to enact tariff changes made by customs tariff proposals in August of this year. These amendments relate to walnuts; large machines imported in separate component form; and deerskin leather garments of New Zealand origin. Also contained in this schedule are:

an amendment to restore the rate of duty applying to polyphenylene oxide. This overcomes an anomaly that has emerged following the introduction of the Government's decision on the chemicals and plastics industries; and

an amendment to additional note 1 to chapter 72 to raise the minimum copper content specification of high alloy steel. This note was prepared some years ago and has been overtaken by changes in the steelmaking industry. The Steel Industry Authority has confirmed that changes in technology have made the restrictions imposed by this note irrelevant to current assistance requirements.

Schedule 2 to the Bill, operative on and from 22 June 1988, restores a rate of duty of 15 per cent to certain paper cutting machines and parts thereof. These amendments were previously included in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1988 retrospective to 1 January 1988. The amendments legally establish the date of operation as 22 June 1988. Complementary amendments are also contained in schedule 1 to the Bill. Schedule 3 to the Bill, operative on and from 1 July 1988, also contains a variety of amendments.
The first amendment is necessary to enact a tariff change made by custom tariff proposals in August of this year. The amendment relates to aviation turbine fuel. Also included in this schedule are:

amendments, consequent on the May economic statement, to provide for the phasing rates of duty and remove the revenue duty applying to certain tariff classifications. A complementary amendment has also been made to part III of schedule 4 of the principal Act to remove redundant item 42c as a result of the removal of the revenue duty;

the imposition of protective rates of duty in certain raw and refined sugar, consequent on the removal of the import embargo on July 1989, which will phase in in accordance with the Government's decision announced in the May economic statement;

amendments to a number of items of schedule 4 to the principal Act, which: rename the Australian industry participation program to the Australian industry involvement program; take account of the new Employment, Education and Training Act 1988; and make it clear that item 22 covers goods for use in natural gas exploration as well as for petroleum exploration;
the remaining amendments of this schedule implement certain wording changes to align the principal Act with the international convention on the harmonised commodity description and coding system.

Schedules 4 and 5, operative on and from 6 July 1988 and 24 August 1988 respectively, enact tariff changes made by tariff proposals in August of this year, relating to fibre glass insect screening; and beer, which was part of the Government's budgetary measures.

Schedule 6 to the Bill, operative on and from 1 January 1989, includes amendments relating to the Government's decision on the chemicals and plastics industries. These exclude certain metallic stearates and vinyl wallpaper from duty phasing arrangements. Also included are other amendments which:
accelerate the phasing-out of New Zealand rates for passenger motor vehicles. Complementary amendments have also been made in schedule 3 relating to components for passenger motor vehicles;

adjust certain Forum islands and developing country rates to accord with the Forum islands and revised developing country preference schemes introduced on 1 July 1986. These rates were not carried through to the harmonised tariff; and
remove redundant item 41d from part III of schedule 4 to the principal Act.

Schedule 7, operative on and from 1 March 1989, contains a series of amendments made in the context of the post-1988 assistance arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries. The amendments include changes to TCF tariff and tariff quota arrangements. They reflect recent Government decisions on the TCF plan, the May economic statement changes to the plan, the outcome of a review by the TCF Development Authority on velvet duty rates, new ANZCERTA-Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement-arrangements, and handicraft textiles and clothing and handmade footwear.

In June 1987 the Government announced the new assistance arrangements for the TCF industries post-1988 TCF plan. The plan commences, in the main, from March 1989 and is aimed at encouraging the restructuring of these industries through a combination of gradual reductions in protection and the provision of special positive adjustment measures. The first of the tariff changes were introduced in legislation in 1987. The proposed legislative changes relate to tariff quota arrangements which will apply from March 1989.
The main changes to the post-1988 TCF plan announced in the May economic statement on 25 May 1988 were:

a reduction in tariffs of five percentage points for apparel and footwear and for most higher tariff rates for fabrics and footwear parts. Because of this reduction a duty surcharge equal to five percentage points will also be introduced where quota is issued on a past import performance basis and base quota duty rates are being reduced. This surcharge will help maintain the relativities between base quota and out-of-quota imports which existed prior to these decisions;
the end of the TCF plan on 30 June 1995, resulting in quota arrangements being abolished eight months earlier than originally announced.

As part of its decision on the TCF plan announced in June 1987, the Government decided that there would be a rationalisation and simplification of textile fabric duty rates. This decision included the duty on imported velvet fabrics being rationalised on 1 January 1988 to 25 per cent. A number of representations were received on this aspect of the decision. After analysis and investigation of the concerns by the TCF Development Authority, the Government decided to reduce the duty to 20 per cent in 1989 and 15 per cent in 1990, and to determine future rates in the mid-term review of the plan.

Also included in this schedule are liberalisation arrangements to accelerate the achievement of full free trade in goods by 1 July 1990. These arrangements were recently decided upon by the Australian and New Zealand governments. New entry arrangements for handicraft textiles and clothing and handmade footwear will also be introduced.

Finally, included are amendments to remove certain tariff classifications from the ambit of the TCF policy. This action now allows the duties applicable to these tariff classifications to be phased in accordance with the rates alterations reductions.
Financial Impact Statement

The restoration of the 10 per cent duty rate for polyphenylene oxide will result in a small decrease in revenue. However, this will be offset in part by the Government's decision to remove the phasing rates currently applying to certain metallic stearates. The change in regard to the copper content of high alloy steel will result in a decrease in revenue not exceeding $1.4m as a result of claims for refund of duties.

Revenue implications flowing from the tariff reductions announced in the Government's May economic statement are difficult to isolate accurately. However, it is anticipated that the reductions covered by this initiative, tariffs which are already phasing, the changes to the passenger motor vehicle plan and the abolition of the 2 per cent revenue duty will result in revenue decreases of $460m in 1988-89 increasing to $900m in 1992-93. The TCF sector currently provides the Government with revenue from the duties levied on imports and from the partial sale by tender of tariff quota.

It is difficult to estimate with any certainty the future budgetary implications of changes in assistance for the TCF sector because of variables such as the phasing out of tariff quotas resulting in a decrease in revenue because of lower tariff rates-however, this will be offset by an increase in revenue resulting from an increase in the volume of imports; liberalisation of trade with New Zealand; replacing quota issued on a past import performance with quota sold by tender; relative competitiveness of Australian production; changes in consumer demand and consumer preferences; and significance of developing countries as import sources.

Notwithstanding these complexities, it is expected that the total revenue collected from the implementation of the post-1988 TCF arrangements, including those arising out of the May economic statement and the closer economic relations changes, should increase by over $200m over the period of the plan. The increase is likely to come largely from the sale of tariff quota by tender. There is expected to be minimal financial impact caused by the other amendments in the Bill. Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you have said, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a cognate debate and, in entering this debate, I wish to confine my remarks to the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1988. The aim of the Bill, as honourable members who have taken note of what the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) said in the second reading speech will know, is to establish a new corporate structure for Telecom Australia. There will be many people across the nation who will welcome the measures being proposed by this Government, particularly as they relate to government business enterprises. The main thrust of this measure is to set up the Australian Telecommunications Corporation, and the measure is part of the Government's reform package, not just for Telecom but, as I have said, for government business enterprises generally. These measures were announced by Senator Gareth Evans on 25 May.

SPEECH.PARA: There are four main elements of reform. The first is revised corporate and financial structures, which will cover so many aspects of government business enterprises; new planning and accountability mechanisms, which everyone wants and would support; the modification of major strategic controls, and the removal of day to day controls of government. In other words, it is supposed to allow those who are in the public sector to run these enterprises on proper commercial bases and to ensure that there is due efficiency. We do not want to see constantly taxpayers' moneys being poured in to prop up business enterprises where this is unnecessary.

However, I want to make the point that for some time Telecom particularly has been involved in a greater efficiency thrust. I think it has met community demand for greater efficiency and accountability. That demand has certainly been heard and has obviously been heeded and a response has been forthcoming. I do not think many Australians really want to go down the full privatisation track. Whilst there has been widespread debate on it, and I can understand honourable members arguing for it, I really do not think it is the consensus of Australians. But they do want efficiency and they do want the best possible service. They want the most efficient delivery of government services, particularly from business enterprises, and they want management of these business enterprises to be responsive to consumer needs. That is happening, and that is the good news.

We can always be critical of Telecom. People will always growl about accounts that they have received or about the cost of installing a new service. But it seems to me, as I have sat with Telecom management over recent times, particularly in my capacity as chairman of the Caucus consumer affairs committee, that there is this responsiveness; that Telecom is prepared to listen to consumers. It is listening to the broader community.

Some time back I received many complaints about the types of telephone bills that people were receiving. People reading this debate or listening to it now will know that we receive at the moment a telephone bill made up of four pages-an innocuous little document that is difficult to understand. There seems to be duplication and a doubling up on the detail that is available. But, for all that, there is a lack of information, and it is not surprising that there has been considerable criticism of the system. It is a computerised system but it just does not seem to have achieved anything from the consumer's point of view.

I took this issue up some months back on the consumer affairs committee when I had the privilege of meeting with Ted Benjamin of Telecom. We talked about all the issues, the complaints, the way that the Australian Pensioners League throughout Queensland and other parts of Australia had argued against the bills and how consumer groups had expressed their concern and their opposition to the bills. In those discussions it was urged that there ought to be a different type of billing format that consumers could understand. We argued also that there should be more information for consumers. They need to know the cost of subscriber trunk dialling (STD) and local calls. Those costs ought not to be lumped in together, as has been the case. We ought to be able to understand what we are being charged for, and that has not been the situation. Consumers have a right to have things in a simple, plain English form so that they know exactly what they are being billed for.

At that time, which was many months ago, Telecom promised to take up the issue and research the complaints that had been put forward. I am now pleased that it has come up with some changes. There will now be a single-page bill. It is being experimented with right at this moment. I am told that Telecom is experimenting with about 500,000 households, which is a large proportion of the households of Australia. It will not be until October next year that the full system will be introduced and in play. But at least the change has come about. It has come about because Telecom has listened to the community, to the consumer groups and to committees such as the parliamentary committee, and it has acted on those requests. It has done the correct thing. It has not just said, `Because politicians have asked for it, we will do it'. It has carried out its research and appreciated that there have been some problems.

Telecom introduced the four-page system for proper reasons. It took on an American or Canadian system, but it just did not work here and so it is going back to a single-page format. More importantly, consumers will get more information about the cost of their STD calls. They will get greater information because the bills will be itemised. Importantly too, as Mr Ted Benjamin told a recent committee meeting, plain English terminology will be used. That must be hailed as a victory for consumers. But Telecom also should be given bouquet for its willingness to sit down with community groups and those affected by its systems, listen to them and then adopt a strategy.

The new strategy will also include a review and rationalisation of the credit management process. There will be additional on-line inquiry details. Telecom is even considering an alternative billing medium, such as a diskette. This is part of a highly consumer oriented approach adopted by Telecom for which it ought to be congratulated. Telecom has issued a very special report. I am very pleased with the substance of the report because it states exactly what will happen. Its heading is `The Telecom Commitment' and it gives a commitment to ensure that the phone bill is easy to understand; that pay telephones work and when people need them; that phone services are at prices that people can afford; that there is quicker, easier installation and maintenance of services; that there is fast and effective response to customer inquiries; and a Telecom organisation that listens and is more attentive to special needs. It is finally happening. It proves that, regardless of the size of any public sector business and regardless of the bureaucratic nature or characteristics of these enterprises, if those in management, those at the head of such structures, are prepared to sit down with consumer groups and others, things can be achieved. I congratulate those involved in Telecom for moving down this track.

The Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO), the pensioner leagues, the committee that I sit on and others have said there has to be a greater bridge. It is not good enough simply to solve the problems after they have arisen. We ought to try to be active in these issues and overcome the problems before they arise. It seems that that will be the outcome because Telecom has now set up, on an interim basis, the Telecom Community Consultative Council. Whilst it is still in its early stages-it is an embryo-type structure at the moment-it would appear from the terms of reference that have been announced and from the types of organisations that will be represented on this Council that the consumer voice will be heard. This Council will have representatives of Telecom and a number of peak consumer organisations. I am pleased to note that AFCO and the Disabled People's International of Australia will have representation. The National Council of Women of Australia, the Australian Consumers Association, the publishers of Choice magazine, the Australian Council of Social Service, the Australian Pensioners Federation and the Rural Telephone Subscribers Association will also have representation. These groups that have been brought together truly represent the vast majority of consumers across this nation in the telecommunications area.

It is early days but the structure should work. It should be a good sounding board to air consumer-related concerns. As I have mentioned before, the types of things that, no doubt, will be discussed are billing, the basic tariffs that are charged and the community service obligations that Telecom ought to embark upon. It will ensure also that there is customer access to Telecom. This seems to have been the biggest problem in the past. I am hoping that this Council will act not only as a sounding board but also, in some ways, as an avenue for redress. Too often in the past it has been Caesar unto Caesar. If one had a complaint against Telecom one had to go to Telecom about Telecom and it was always very difficult to get a solution. In the past I have had people in my electorate who have been angry over the size of the bill they got and the Telecom manager would say, `We will monitor it over the next three months'. When the bill fell considerably these people would go back and be told by the accounts section that the bill from the past still had to be paid and the only reason that it had dropped in the last three months was that these people had been more careful with their use of the telephone. So people could never win. People were told that the technological integrity of the system in Telecom was such that they could not challenge it; that these machines did not make mistakes. But there were instances where mistakes had been made. The main thing was that people did not believe that they were getting a fair hearing.

The new Council ought to be a bridge of understanding between Telecom and consumers. That was the point made by Mel Ward, Telecom's Managing Director. He actually used the phrase `a bridge of understanding'. I hope that that will generate not only a working environment but also a climate of trust in which there will be a free exchange of views and, most importantly, many of the problems that Telecom has faced in the past with consumers will be headed off. I want to pay a special tribute to Ted Benjamin. Whilst he has worked with many other people in the corporate area of Telecom, he seems to have given so much of the lead in bringing about these changes. I am sure that the Council will act as a consultative body and also as a lobby group because it will mean that the 62 organisations that belong to AFCO, the many individuals who belong to the Australian Consumers Association, the hundreds of people who work through those organisations in the isolated telephone subscriber areas and the 1.37 million pensioners will have their say because they will be represented on this Council.

I suggest that one thing that this Council ought to look at fairly quickly is the anomalous area that relates to the community access program. It has been a wonderful idea. It means that people in country areas have been able to get cheaper calls because they have been given a township nearby where they would normally deal commercially, educationally, legally and so on. But it would appear that too many of the decisions in drawing up the maps and in drawing the rings around areas have been taken by people who do not understand the areas, particularly in country Queensland. I refer in particular to central Queensland, which I represent. Some strange anomalies have arisen and, despite an effort to overcome them and despite efforts to get the decisions turned around, I have not been successful.

The idea of community access is good in principle. It has meant cheaper phone calls for many people and it has meant access to the centres of importance to them. But the anomalies exist. Whilst I give credit to the local and regional Telecom management in my area for achieving some changes, we still have a fair way to go to ensure that there is that degree of sameness that we all desire. I give as an example the people who live in the Mackenzie River area. The Mackenzie River flows about 200 kilometres from Rockhampton in the highlands of central Queensland and there are a number of farmers in the area. I have about 34 farms in my region. These farmers are linked to a township called Blackwater, which is on the Capricorn Highway directly west of Rockhampton. Blackwater is a wonderful place in which to live. It is a mining town with 8,000 or 9,000 people, but the point is that it is a mining town. It does not normally cater for farmers. It does not have facilities such as stock and station agents, equipment suppliers and repair facilities for farmers.

The people of the Mackenzie River area have been given community access to Blackwater. If we look at the map we see that it is a quite ridiculous thing. If we look at the biggest dots on the map of the area we see that Blackwater would be the biggest dot closest to the Mackenzie River area. But if we look at the road systems we see that the people of the Mackenzie River area must go through a place called Dingo to get to Blackwater. Dingo just happens to be linked to Rockhampton for community access.

TALK.START.PARA: —They clearly don't have the knowledge of the local member.

—I take the honourable member's point-they do not have the knowledge of the local member. This has been done despite representations by me as the Federal member for the area and despite a survey that showed that 99.9 per cent of the people wanted Rockhampton as their point of access because their kids go there for educational purposes-there are residential colleges in Rockhampton-because they use Rockhampton for their banking services as all commercial activities take place in Rockhampton and because all the legal services and medical services are operated from Rockhampton. In the wisdom of the people concerned in Telecom who, regrettably are situated in Melbourne-I know that that is a wonderful city as well but they are there and I do not think they know much about central Queensland-the people of the Mackenzie River area have been attached to Blackwater. This is an anomalous situation and one that ought to be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: I give as a second example the Callide Valley, another area that I represent as the member for the thirteenth largest electorate in this nation. The townships of Baralaba, Dululu, Wowan and Jambin are linked under community access to Mount Morgan. Mount Morgan is a wonderful place. It is five or six degrees cooler than Rockhampton. It is a living museum in itself. It really is a pleasant place to be. If I could get down the range more quickly and not get caught by the road trains and so on, I would not mind living in Mount Morgan and servicing my electorate from there. But it is a small township that does not have the facilities that the people of Baralaba, Dululu and Jambin want. They are all part of what is called the Banana Shire. The Banana Shire is situated in the township of Biloela. These people are linked to Mount Morgan. When the survey was run and Telecom management met with the people at a public meeting, the people argued first and foremost for Rockhampton and, secondly, for Biloela. They did not really care which one they got, provided they got one. Whether it be the local government services, medical services or farming services of Biloela or the other educational, legal, commercial and banking services of Rockhampton, these people wanted community access to either of those places. Instead they have been locked into Mount Morgan.

As I have said, a survey was run and the vast majority of people wanted either Biloela or Rockhampton. Instead, probably because Mount Morgan is a bigger black dot on the map when one looks at its relationship to Dululu, Wowan and Baralaba, in the wisdom of Telecom these people have been locked into Mount Morgan.

The third example is on the north coast of my electorate-the townships of St Lawrence and Ogmore. These two places have been given Sarina as their community access point. I grew up in Sarina. I went to school there and then taught there before going to Rockhampton and then moving to some of the smaller schools in central Queensland. Sarina is a wonderful place, a great place for kids to grow up in, but it does not have the facilities needed by the people of St Lawrence, which is the centre of cattle country. Sarina does not have those facilities. The people of St Lawrence want Mackay as their access centre because it is the centre of legal, commercial and other services. Admittedly, Sarina has lawyers and doctors but the people of St Lawrence have made a choice. They believe that under the whole concept of community access, they would be better off being linked into Mackay. But they have not been; they have been linked to Sarina.

Those are just three examples and regrettably there are many more. I know that I am being parochial, but this demonstrates the point that while Telecom is being more consumer-oriented and is willing to listen to what people are saying, in this case we have an example of people in Telecom in Melbourne sitting in their leather chairs and not understanding what it is like to live in country areas. These people have looked at the maps and chosen the biggest dots. They have linked the rural and farming areas to the biggest dots without even looking at the road systems. I urge the new council to take up these matters and reactivate the surveys that have been conducted. I suggest that council members talk to the Telecom administration in central Queensland and not only review the situation but also bring about change. I welcome the overall new approach and I suggest that in theory it will work well, but time will tell whether it will be as effective as the theory says.

The people who will be administering our Telecom region will be city based. They will have the concerns of city people and will not have the understandings of country people. We believe that it is terribly important for the Telecom customers in our region to continue to receive a decentralised administration operating from Goulburn.

We have received a wonderful service from the Telecom district office at Goulburn. As a Federal member of parliament I know, as would all honourable members, that Telecom's operations are probably the most criticised function of the Federal Government within our own local areas. This is not an unreasonable occurrence, given the nature of the service provided by Telecom and the difficulties of maintaining that service. Despite all those difficulties and the numbers of complaints that a Federal member of parliament must always expect to receive, the service that I have received in dealing with complaints on behalf of constituents, through the Goulburn Telecom administrative office, has been first-rate. With very few exceptions, we have been able to resolve our problems without having to go to higher authorities. We have had wonderful service and we want that to continue in the future. We are fearful that we will not receive that service once Telecom's administration shifts to Campbelltown and becomes dominated by city-based interests.

In addition to that, I find it ludicrous not only that Telecom is proposing to shift its administration from Goulburn to Campbelltown but also that the administration of all of country New South Wales Telecom activities is from Sydney itself. If Telecom is as good at providing communication services as it claims it is, then surely Telecom's country administration could be from places such as Goulburn, Dubbo, Orange or Bathurst. They are all close to major airports and all have Telecom services for telex and facsimile machines and all the latest telephone services. Whether one is in Sydney, Bathurst, Orange, Dubbo, Goulburn or wherever in the country areas, one is still able to communicate just as well from there as from Sydney if Telecom is doing its job properly.

I think it would be an act of good faith for Telecom to shift the administration of its New South Wales country services from Sydney to one of the main regional centres of New South Wales. I am sure that as a result, it would be providing the people in country areas of New South Wales with a better service. If Telecom is to cater for its customers, decentralise its activities and give the very best possible service to the people for whom it exists, it is important that it not only shift its operations for its country administration from Sydney to the bush but also ensure that areas such as Goulburn are administered by locally based administrative offices. I think that is a crucial consideration for the future of Telecom.

While speaking of Telecom, I am very pleased to see that Goulburn is about to receive mobile telephone services. Nowra which is on the eastern end of the electorate of Gilmore-a very fast growing and rapidly developing area-is in desperate need of a mobile telephone service. That service was supposed to be up and running by September of this year but we are yet to see any evidence of it. It was originally promised a couple of years ago, but for various reasons the Government has not been able to meet that commitment. We look forward to the day that it does because it will add further to the growth, the development and the lifestyle of the people in the Nowra region.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might get caught!

—People have to be very cautious of how they talk on mobile telephones. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Senator Richardson and a whole host of other members of State and Federal parliaments have discovered over a period of time, one has to be very careful. I am sure my constituents will be most cautious in the way they conduct their conversations on mobile phones. We want to have the privilege and right to use them and we look forward to Telecom delivering us that privilege in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to move to the Bill that deals with railway services through the Australian National Railways Commission. Last year I took a ride from Alice Springs to Adelaide on the Australian National Railways train, commonly called the Ghan. This is one of the most historic train rides, not only in Australia but also throughout the world. According to train buffs it is one of the best train rides in the world. Having ridden on it, I believe that whilst the service is very good it certainly could be improved to capture the rapidly growing tourist market in Australia. As honourable members know, tourism is our fastest growing industry today. We have had an average increase of 27 per cent in foreign visitors to our country in each of the last four years. We have 2.25 million to 2.4 million foreign visitors this year. It is expected that something like five million-and people are now saying that we could have in excess of seven million-international visitors will visit our country by the year 2000. This represents huge potential to all sorts of facets of Australian life. The Ghan is one of those facets of our Australian way of life that could cash in on the potential for tourism.

I believe that Australian National ought to be looking at upgrading several of its carriages to provide first-rate, world-class facilities, with accommodation and service to cater for the increasingly sophisticated range of tourists travelling not only to the eastern coast of Australia but also to the heart of Australia, to Ayers Rock and Alice Springs. There is a rapid growth in the number of international visitors going to those places. International visitors are looking for a unique experience; they are not seeking to have another look at the inside of a five-star hotel room. They are looking to experience something that is different-and the Ghan is different, in the way that a ride on the Orient Express is different. If Australian National can upgrade the standard of its accommodation and services, it will find within a very short time that it will have created a lucrative market for itself by catering to the sophisticated tourist, now very evident in Australia.

Goulburn, the centre of the electorate of Gilmore, as I mentioned earlier, is one of the great train cities of Australia. Goulburn has experienced a gradual rundown in the number of people employed within the railways over the last couple of years, unfortunately mostly under the previous New South Wales Labor Government: but we look forward to a very exciting future because, as the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) said earlier on in this debate, the very fast train that will be running between Sydney and Melbourne will be going through Goulburn, as it will be going through a number of centres one of which is Canberra. The very fast train will be a great boost to the city of Goulburn, as it will be to all those places on its course. I am just hoping that the Federal Government and the Victorian and New South Wales governments will do all within their power to ensure that the very fast train becomes a reality and that those people who are the backers of the very fast train can see fit to find the finances and establish the viability to go ahead with the project.

We can see this project putting Goulburn very much on the map. We will be only 48 minutes travelling time to Central Station in Sydney and 15 minutes travelling time to Canberra. It will revolutionise our concept of transport and communication in Australia. Australia is a large country. We are a few people scattered around this great land, and one of the greatest things we can do is provide a very cheap and accessible form of physical communication between the two major cities of Australia. I fully support the very fast train and congratulate Dr Paul Wild, who of course has been the driving influence behind the whole concept of developing the very fast train. I just hope that it can proceed.

The very fast train is particularly relevant to our discussion earlier in the afternoon about the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. If we can take some of the heavy load off the airport by putting some of those domestic travellers on the very fast train, we will find that we will delay some of the serious and chronic problems that Sydney Airport faces.

To finish up, I once again come back to the urgent need to maintain the administration of Goulburn's Telecom district within Goulburn to better enable Telecom to cater for its customers. I look forward to seeing Australian National capitalise on the tremendous growth in tourism in Australia today by upgrading its Ghan services, and I also look forward to the day I can ride from Canberra to Goulburn in the very fast train in the quick time of 15 minutes. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating cognately six Bills, and in my remarks I want to focus on the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, which will convert the Overseas Telecommunications Commission into a public company, the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation. As with all the organisations we are dealing with today, OTC is being converted into a government-owned public company as a result of a report entitled Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises, released by the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, last May. This report, in turn, built on the principles laid down by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in his statement on government business enterprises in November last year. Both of these statements stressed that government supervision of organisations like OTC must concentrate on clarifying aims and getting results, rather than stressing detailed scrutiny of day to day operations, if they are to meet Australia's economic and social needs effectively and efficiently.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, as the document released by Senator Evans pointed out, excessive scrutiny of government enterprises has not brought results. It says:
In fact, the evidence is to the contrary.

If we want results it is far better to tell organisations like OTC what we want, set strict financial and performance standards and insist that they are met. Rather than continually meddle in essence, we should let the managers manage. As a former public servant myself, I know what happens-or, rather, does not happen-when governments continually fiddle with the day to day running of public administration instead of concentrating on what they want that administration to do for them. In the end, means become confused with ends, both continually change and government becomes a process of reaction and muddling through. Fortunately, this Government is alert to those dangers and, by introducing program budgeting and giving Public Service managers more autonomy, it has acted to avert them.

Indeed, restructuring and reforming the public sector is an essential part of the Government's micro-economic reform agenda, on which so much of its energy is being concentrated during its third term, as it possibly will be into a fourth term. In the present difficult and fiercely competitive international trading environment public sector efficiency is critical. As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) has suggested, nowhere is this more important than in the transport and communications sector, where public business enterprises produce not only final goods and services for the consumer but also provide intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, and thus influence the nation's overall cost structures. So, naturally, it is imperative that organisations like OTC do their work as efficiently as possible.

Fortunately, through a combination of good management and good luck, having faced comparatively little political interference in its day to day operations over the years, OTC already has a fine reputation for its efficiency. Indeed, not only is it one of the most profitable government enterprises in terms of return on investment-making a profit of $190.4m this year, an increase of 52 per cent on previous years-but also it is the lowest cost provider of international telephone calls, over distance, in the world. Despite all the claims made about the supposed efficiency of American telephone companies, a study by the international telecommunications consultants NUS International found that OTC could provide a three-minute call to the United States for $A5.40, while the cheapest cost of a call going the other way, provided by an American company, was $A8.60, about 50 per cent more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outstanding.

—It is an outstanding performance, as the honourable member for Perth points out. So it is not surprising to learn that there is no need to alter OTC's financial structure or inject private capital in order to turn the organisation into a public company. With a debt to equity ratio of 65 : 35, OTC is well placed to operate in the marketplace as an autonomous company.

SPEECH.PARA: Incorporation as a public company will enable OTC to build on this by allowing it the freedom to compete more effectively with its international rivals. With 1987-88 revenue of $1,167m and a growth rate in service demand of around 15 to 20 per cent it clearly has the cash flow to do this. It is thus well placed to take a leading role in expanding Australian exports of high technology and high value added goods and services, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. Such markets offer very great potential for Australian services exporters like OTC. For example, a recent United States study estimated that by 1992 there would be more than 32,000 satellite earth stations installed in developing countries. An estimated 38 per cent of those will go into our region, the Asia-Pacific region.

The potential market for OTC's consultancy skills, systems engineering skills and project engineering and coordinating, is highly promising. Moreover, if other Australian suppliers can join with OTC to provide affordable, dependable telecommunications systems for the countries of Asia and the Pacific, there will be great benefit for the Australian economy as a whole. The opportunities are there to do so. OTC's strength is as a service provider rather than purely and simply as a manufacturer. There are ample opportunities for Australian manufacturers to supply the bits and pieces-the computer software, ground systems, generators, solar panels and prefabricated buildings-which go in to setting up telecommunications networks. Anyone who doubts this should look hard at OTC's track record in recent times, especially since the formation last year of its wholly owned subsidiary, OTC International.

As Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I am pleased to be able to point out that the most recent example of the success that OTC has had in this region is the fact that OTC won approval from the South Pacific Forum to set up a $140m regional satellite communications network. Tiny countries in the Pacific are separated by vast distances over sea and have a vital need for communications systems. Not only will this network go a long way to solving the communications needs of a geographically disparate region like the Pacific, but it will do so at a price which Forum nations can afford. Furthermore, a consortium of Australian companies stands a good chance of winning the $75m contract to provide 100 seven-metre satellite dishes to serve the system. To this end, OTC and the companies involved have already spent $18m on a cooperative research and development program aimed at producing hardware for the network. Even more encouraging is the fact that if Australia wins the dish contract there is not only the chance of a repeat order for dishes five years down the track, but also of OTC being asked to set up a similar network in Africa. The spin-offs could be considerable.

These are not the only international opportunities which OTC has. Last year the organisation won contracts to design, construct and install satellite earth stations in Laos, Vietnam and Malta. Australian-made components and Australian expertise are involved in each project. As many honourable members may have noted, several weeks ago OTC won back one of the world's largest and most prestigious space communications management contracts. The contract, worth $40m over 10 years, is for the management of Intelsat satellites over the Indian and Pacific Oceans. It requires OTC to build a number of antennae using expertise developed here for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Australia Telescope.

It is evident that in OTC we have not only a competitive government enterprise, but also one that has the capacity to generate significant foreign exchange revenue. In doing so it does more than set an example to other Australian companies; it puts them to shame. Unlike many Australian companies, OTC has not been afraid to look for overseas markets or to spend money on research and development to ensure that it provides internationally competitive products and services. Indeed, so highly does OTC value research and development that it has a separate research and development board composed of six highly qualified scientists and technical experts. This board presides over OTC's sizeable research and development budget-over half of which is spent on commissioning research in tertiary institutions and by industry-and ensures the OTC's investment in overseas equipment guarantees technology transfer to Australia.

With demand for its services increasing at 20 per cent per annum, OTC is committed to investing $2,000m in new facilities and networks over the next decade to provide the capacity-nine times the total now available-to meet customers' needs to the turn of the century. This expansion of facilities, both here and overseas, through OTC International, can only boost the rapidly expanding Australian telecommunications equipment industry.

It is obvious that OTC is well suited to be converted to a public company and, indeed, will benefit from that occurring. As the discussion paper released by Senator Gareth Evans last May noted, conversion into a public company will remove the final impediments to OTC's expansion, while retaining government ownership removes the risk of its central position in Australia's national infrastructure being exploited by an unscrupulous owner if it were privatised. So it is with pleasure that I commend the Bill to the House. OTC is an organisation that is both efficient and effective and, as such, it gives the lie to claims that public enterprises cannot operate competitively in the market-place. This one can, does, and will continue to do so.

The OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988 amends the Overseas Telecommunications Act and deems OTC to be a public company. Like the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988, introduced by the former Minister for Transport and Communications Support and present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), this approach is consistent with that adopted for Australian Airlines' conversion to company status. As the same legal entity is transferred to company status there is no need to rewrite existing contracts and the like. The date for conversion is set by proclamation-at this stage intended to be 1 January 1989.

OTC Ltd will be expected to operate like other companies under the Companies Code. This means most of the provisions of the Overseas Telecommunications Act will not be needed and can be repealed. Included among these are provisions which deal with staffing matters. The Bill includes provisions to ensure continuity of employment and the maintenance of existing accrued entitlements for each employee, upon conversion of OTC to a company. There will be appropriate mechanisms to allow the Minister to exercise strategic oversight, through the corporate plan and financial targets. OTC will be free to engage, on its own authority, in such standard business practices as entering into contracts, partnerships, joint ventures, and normal business investment arrangements. The Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth. OTC's performance, and Australia's performance in the foreign market-place, can only benefit from this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My learned colleague on the other side of the House, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), was attacked by bogong moths while he spoke. I have observed that a number of them are flying around the chamber. Whilst the lights of the building may have been turned off for the past two nights, all of the residual moths appear to have remained in this chamber. Perhaps, Mr Deputy Speaker, this matter can be taken up with the Speaker to ascertain what can be done about them.

SPEECH.PARA: The House is debating cognately six Bills which the Government has introduced concerning government business enterprises, which change slightly the nature of those enterprises. I say `slightly' because I do not think the Government has bitten the bullet and done nearly enough to make those enterprises competitive and integrated into the Australian economy by way of privatisation; that is, by selling government enterprises on appropriate terms to the public sector, either by way of the whole of the capital or part of the capital, so that money can be raised and they can make profits. Because they would no longer be financed by the public purse, they would no longer be a burden on, or responsible to, taxpayers. Privatisation will make those organisations less bureaucratic as Public Service structures will not apply to them. They will be subject to competition in the marketplace. It is only by competition in the marketplace that one can get effective enterprise and better service for the public. Competition is very much the key to it.

This cognate debate about government business enterprises is interesting because the introduction of these pieces of legislation in this cognate way is an admission by the Government of failure of policy. It shows its confused approach which arises out of a number of inconsistent statements by Government Ministers, in fact by the Australian Labor Party, as to where the Government is going in relation to privatisation. We do not know the current position of the Government. There was an initial rush under the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to privatise, to get off the Government's books a number of enterprises. Those measures would have Opposition support because we believe that a number of government enterprises should not be on the government books. They should be sold to the private sector, where they could carry on business and be responsible for raising funds for capital expansion. Funds are needed for capital expansion by many business enterprises. For example, Qantas Airways Ltd at the present time needs of the order of $600m. Rather than taxpayers having to pay for it out of their taxes-it is their taxes at work-I say to the people of Australia, `Let us make the private sector raise that money in the marketplace by borrowings, by issuing of capital and by normal mechanisms that are used by private enterprises. Let the private sector get it off the Government's books'.

The Treasurer was rushing in that direction. Someone in the Left, perhaps the Centre Left, put up a stop sign and said, `Halt! Look, you've gone too far too quickly. This isn't in accordance with Labor Party policy. Our traditional voters, who we're losing by the bucketloads at by-elections, don't like this because there's some featherbedding going on in many sectors of the economy'. The stop sign went up and we are left with this sort of mishmash of cognate Bills that are really an apology for privatisation. In effect they do very little and in most cases they do nothing. It is a case of too little too late. It shows the confused nature of the Government's policy approach towards privatisation.

The Treasurer initially rushed off and started selling assets to raise money. Remember the banana republic statements. We sold the Tokyo Embassy for of the order of $600m, if I recall correctly. I would imagine that the value of that site has doubled since it was sold. That shows what a good sale that was! My own view is that it was a tragedy that it was ever sold. It should never have been sold. It was a national asset. We lost face and we were severely embarrassed in the eyes of the Japanese Government and the Japanese people because Australia, which had this magnificent holding in the middle of Tokyo, sold it to raise money to pay its debts. Similarly the Ambassador's residence in Paris, a lovely residence that had been owned for many years by consecutive Australian governments, was sold. I understand that it has been resold since for at least a 50 per cent increase on the price it was sold for by the Australian Government. I imagine it is now worth double the price it was sold for. I make those comments in passing to show, as I said a second ago, the totally confused nature and the inconsistent approach of the Government in relation to privatisation.

One of the Bills before us is the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill. It is an interesting Bill. Another interesting Bill before us is the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill. It shows that the Government is taking a step but we do not know what the next step is. We do not know where we are going after this. It is a step that merely makes these business enterprises public companies. We do not know what the next measure is. The Government may as well have done nothing.

The ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill is interesting because it does not grasp, deal with or take on the real issues. It shows that the bottom line in the labour movement, the Australian Labor Party, is that the parliamentary party is the parliamentary wing of the union movement. There is no dispute about that. That is a matter of fact, a matter of record and a matter of history. We have the parent, the union movement, saying, `You can't do anything about reforming anything on the waterfront or in relation to coastal shipping'. The maritime unions have in fact said to the Government, `Hey, stop. You can't be efficient and competitive, because we've got a lot of work practices on the waterfront. We're in fact doing pretty nicely out of this'. Because of this the Australian public has suffered, as has been shown in a most excellent report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on coastal shipping dated July this year. I challenge the Government to grasp the nettle of the findings of that report. Many of the facts were well known but this report really puts it on the table and makes it a matter of record for the Government to deal with. The report says:
The major factors accounting for-
it refers to the inefficient outcome of the practices-

. . . are the effective exclusion of competition from foreign-flag vessels under the Navigation Act, combined with a number of other regulatory and institutional factors both at sea . . . (including restrictive union practices).

One of the keys is that these restrictive union practices are putting the costs of coastal shipping up so that Australia is uncompetitive and the Australian taxpayer is having to pay the bill, as is the Australian consumer, of exorbitant shipping costs around the coast of Australia. We all know about the maritime unions. We know about the Seamen's Union of Australia. It really caused a shock to this Government in this our bicentennial year when we had visits from navies of the Western alliance. Many of the ships could not get into Australian ports because the maritime unions, in particular the Seamen's Union in Melbourne, where I come from, said, `You can't get in'. We had the crazy situation of the HMS Ark Royal, the Royal Navy aircraft carrier, anchored off Melbourne with the crew being unable to get ashore because the Seamen's Union said, `You can't berth' and would not make the tugs available. That showed that the unions control what goes on at the waterfront.
Let me go back to the IAC report because it is interesting. It says of the coastal shipping industry as a whole:
. . . remains inefficient and uncompetitive relative to those in maritime nations with similar standards of living.

Major inefficiencies (both on-board and on-shore) manifest themselves in the form of excessive costs and unavoidable delays which erode the international competitiveness of Australian industries and jeopardise growth and employment prospects elsewhere in the economy.

I have read that to the House and into Hansard because is it significant. This industry, an important transport industry, remains inefficient and uncompetitive. We have here a government that has been in power for 5 1/2 years. We have here a government that says it is trying to restructure the Australian economy. It is frightful that 5 1/2 years down the track, after an internal stop-go debate in the Labor Party as to whether we should privatise, the answer is that because of the factions and the unions we cannot privatise. So we have this crazy situation on the waterfront of enormously high costs of an inefficient and uncompetitive industry.

One of the things the Government must do is restructure the economy. I think the Government accepts that. But we in the Opposition say that the rate of restructuring is too slow and after 5 1/2 years the Government has got nowhere on the waterfront. The situation is as bad as it was when the Government came to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think restructuring began in the Fraser period?
—No. I acknowledge the interjection from the Minister.
—It began in shipping under Ralph Hunt as Minister.

—The former Minister, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), started it because he realised the problems of the industry. This Government should have picked up on what the honourable member for Gwydir started and accepted the challenge of restructuring the economy because, if Australia is going to be a competitive, efficient economy playing its part in the world economy as an important trading nation, we have to solve problems that exist in industries such as the coastal shipping industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the future of Australia is one of a great trading nation, and a global trading nation. Shipping is important and vital to, in fact the lifeblood of, most imports and exports. If we are going to be global, if we are still going to have markets in Europe, buy from and sell to the United States of America and trade with the whole world, we must have an efficient, competitive and effective coastal shipping industry. Even more importantly, Australia, as a global trading nation-I believe that there is an enormous potential for Australia to be a global trading power-has to place an emphasis on the region in which we live-the Asia-Pacific region. That is where all the growth is occurring in the world at present. It is where the growth economies are-the tigers of Thailand and Taiwan; the strongest economy in the world, the Japanese economy; and Korea. The President of the Republic of Korea is arriving in Australia today, I think. Those are the nations that have restructured, that are competitive. Those nations do not have featherbedded, inefficient and uncompetitive industries like the Australian coastal shipping industry. Those are the nations with which Australia has to deal, trade and compete.

If Australians are to have a future, we must have an efficient economy. An efficient economy will provide jobs for Australians. The challenge for governments is to restructure the Australian economy at a rate that will make us competitive as quickly as possible. The tragedy is that we are now falling behind. The introduction of this legislation shows that the Government is not prepared to bite the bullet. Our inflation rate is still double that of our major trading partners. Our costs are still going up. We are out of balance and out of kilter with our major trading partners. That means that we will fall behind. As we remain uncompetitive and fall behind, the standard of living will fall. While the Government fiddles in relation to privatisation while Rome burns, the standard of living of Australians falls and the Government fails to grasp the nettle in restructuring the economy.

A number of these Bills before the House today involve part of the micro-economy. I am talking about coastal shipping but we are also debating the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill and the Postal Services Amendment Bill. It is a pity that the Government has not grasped the nettle firmly.
I return to coastal shipping and the excellent report of the IAC. I will quote other parts of the report, because it is significant. The report states:

The Commission estimates that if international freight rates applied on the coast then coastal shipping freight rates covering the ship-and shore-based segments of the industry would, on average, be between 20 and 50 per cent lower in most years.

That is a reduction of between 20 and 50 per cent in coastal shipping freight rates immediately, if international freight rates apply. We have a highly protected coastal shipping industry. The Commission goes on to say:
This would yield a direct saving of between $180m and $460m on the costs of freight services (on a wharfgate-to-wharfgate basis).
These are incredible savings to Australian industry and Australian consumers. The Commission goes on to say:
When the flow on effects on the rest of the economy are taken into account, Australia's real gross domestic product could increase by between $250m and $550m . . .
So, not only could we cut costs and become more competitive, but also we could increase real gross domestic product by having a growing, dynamic economy. The IAC continues:
The total benefits to the economy would be much larger than the above estimates suggest because they make no allowance for:
the substantial costs of avoidable delays; opportunities for further processing of raw materials in Australia; and
the benefits that could arise from rationalising domestic production and distribution.

Benefits would arise from a rationalisation of domestic production and distribution. Obviously, there is a distortion at present because of high coastal shipping industry costs. If we had a rationalisation of road freight, rail freight and air freight we would have total competition between different forms of transport-a totally competitive transport economy. In a trading nation the size of Australia-transporting goods from east to west and north to south-whose lifeblood is trade to and from the rest of the world, because we are an island continent, shipping is important to get products from east to west, from the mines and factories around the coast. It is important that the economy enjoy the cost reductions and the benefits that would flow from a rationalised, competitive transport system-each form of transport being competitive with the other. The Government has failed dramatically to bite the bullet in relation to the Australian National Line (Conversion into Public Company) Bill.
Again I quote from the Industries Assistance Commission report:

A more efficient coastal shipping industry would attract potential users who presently use alternative transport modes and pay more than they would if competitive coastal shipping services were available.

That is the point I made a minute or two ago about the need for a totally competitive transport system. I conclude with a quotation I referred to earlier from the Industries Assistance Commission report referring to the factors that I have discussed:
The major factors accounting for this outcome are the effective exclusion of competition from foreign-flag vessels under the Navigation Act . . .

In other words, Australia excludes competition. We will not allow competition from overseas shipping lines. We are afraid of competition. But, if we do not have competition, we will have an inefficient and ineffective industry. The IAC report then refers to a number of other regulatory and institutional factors, including restrictive union practices. The final paragraph of the findings of the Commission states:

Real and lasting benefits will only be achieved if competitive influences are allowed to operate in both the sea-based and shore-based segments of the industry; to pursue further reform at sea without effectively addressing reform on the waterfront would be an exercise in futility.
