—Thank you. I look forward to the competition.

—From my experience, most of those who are interested in free enterprise or who are devotees of such spend most of their time trying to eliminate the competition, creating a monopoly where they are able to control the market totally. That is the Government's concern about government business enterprises such as those within the ambit of legislation we are discussing today: the Australian National Line (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988, the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill 1988, the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1988, the Satellite Communications Amendment Bill 1988 and the Postal Services Amendment Bill 1988. Earlier in the year we discussed the Qantas Airways Ltd legislation and the Australian Airlines legislation. It is our concern that there should be competition in those areas. Were we to make a move to privatise Australian Airlines, one of our concerns would be that a monopoly was not created in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically I would like to speak about the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC). The honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) has already put a strong and cogent case in respect of the OTC and the effectiveness with which it presently functions as a government business enterprise. Perhaps the most telling statistic he produced is that relating to OTC's cost of telephone calls. Of course telephone revenue is the bulk of its revenue. He made the point that a three-minute call from Australia to the United States costs the Australian consumer $4.50, whereas a call made the other way-which is exactly the same distance, as he pointed out-costs the US consumer $8.60. So the role of OTC is one which benefits Australian consumers greatly.

It is important for us to look at OTC's history. Overseas telecommunications services between Australia and the rest of the world commenced in 1871 with the completion of the submarine telegraph cable to Darwin, inaugurating the overseas telegram or cable service. This service was later operated by Cable and Wireless Ltd and remained unchallenged until 1927. Of course, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, probably has these facts at his fingertips, as he seems to have most facts at his fingertips. When Amalgamated Wireless opened a competing beam wireless telephonic service in 1930 there was considerable competition between the two. There was concern because the less costly radio service threatened the demise of the more reliable cable service. That was a very sensitive matter. During the Second World War governments became very concerned about the integrity of telecommunications. It was in 1946 that the Overseas Telecommunications Act was established and OTC came into being. That followed very sensitive times. Since then, OTC has grown into a very aggressive and successful company. I suppose that it is the nature of the outreaching activities of OTC, the nature of telecommunications and the rapid way in which technology has expanded in this area that has made this service very successful.

The point was made by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) in his speech that the operating profit of this organisation was up 16 per cent in the year ended 31 March 1987. During 1986-87 a dividend was set at $40m for OTC, and the Commonwealth Government's total take in dividend and taxation was nearly $100m in that year. So we can see that this is an organisation which is making a substantial contribution to Australia's Budget. It is also an organisation which is providing a great deal of the impetus to research and development in a very high tech area, an area in which there are considerable markets and potential for Australia as an overseas supplier to be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from its non-quantifiable social benefits.

—Yes. On top of the very practical and pragmatic work that is being done by OTC, it provides Australia with social and political advantages which are very significant for those many Australians who have settled in this country and who have ties all over the world. Australia, which has had a significant immigration program for many years, has large numbers of Australians have ties all over the world. Telecommunications is very important as the world gets smaller and as we become increasingly part of a world community. It is very important in a personal sense and for businesses. Communications from Australia to all parts of the world will be vital in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate on these pieces of legislation invariably turns to privatisation. From honourable members on the other side of the House we hear how important it is that the Government should sell all these enterprises and that we should be pursuing the miracle of Margaret Thatcher who has in some way turned around the economy in the United Kingdom. But if one looks closely at the figures, one will see that there is reason for concern about the United Kingdom privatisation model that is being pursued there. If one looks at the United Kingdom's economy at the moment, it is fair to say that it is heading for a balance of payments crisis which is highly reminiscent of another period of conservative government which began in the 1970s. If one looks at manufacturing output in Britain one will be interested to note that there has been a steady fall in the balance of manufacturing trade in Great Britain which is offset only by significant increases of revenue received from oil expenditure. As those reserves of oil reduce over the next few years the Thatcher Government will face an enormous problem.

But more importantly, one needs to look at what was supposed to happen when privatisation occurred in the United Kingdom. It was suggested that there would be some significant increase in managerial competence as a result of the privatisation of a large number of nationalised industries in that country. But one has not seen that occurring. One has seen a demand led boom in the United Kingdom rather than a massive increase in efficiency of those industries which have been privatised. In fact, many figures indicate that those organisations which have remained under the control of the public purse in the United Kingdom have shown much greater increases in productivity. Perhaps it is because of the threat of privatisation. Nonetheless, it is very important that that point be made.

When privatisation occurs, one master replaces another. There has been a massive increase in the amount of legislation required in the United Kingdom to control all of those industries which have been supposedly privatised. Some observers have described the situation as a regulatory bonanza. The Government has simply substituted one form of external state intervention, that is nationalisation, with another, that is regulation. Regulatory agencies in the United Kingdom conduct rate of return regulation, pricing regulation, policy of service regulation and, again, there are many questions being asked as to whether the new masters are any better or effective than those who were there previously. I have been an outspoken supporter of partial privatisation of one or two of the Government's industries, but it is increasingly my view when I look at OTC that that is not the most appropriate response in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Australian Airlines and Qantas?

—I am already on record with respect to those two organisations. When one looks at this organisation one will see that clearly it has been functioning very effectively in a commercial sense for some time now. It does not have the crisis of cash flow that exists in one or two other areas, so we will not be making significant demands on taxpayers' money. It is providing consumers with an outstanding service. It is very cost efficient and it provides some integrity to Australia's security if there should be any threat.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern about the selling off of public enterprises is what happens to the profits. If we look at British Telecom, British Gas, British Airways or Rolls Royce, we will see that the first instalment of shares that was made available on the share market reaped a windfall profit to those who were able to get hold of them initially. The opening price for British Telecom shares was 93p whereas the shares were available on the first instalment at 50p. So there was an 86 per cent profit from the day the shares went on to the market to the first day of ownership. There were windfall profits to be made for those who were able to get hold of those shares.

It is human nature for people to choose to take those profits. We find that over time the ownership of those shares is not spread amongst large numbers of shareholders, but increasingly is becoming centralised and located amongst one or two larger groups. That is of concern. The same applies when one looks at British Gas or British Airways. In the first instalment their shares were available at 65p, but they came onto the market at 109p, a 68 per cent profit straight off. There is the concern that, should the decision be made to privatise, there is the possibility of those shares very quickly being controlled by small groups because small investors would be encouraged to take their immediate profit. Unfortunately, the dream of having a nation of shareholders that Margaret Thatcher talked about may well fall to its feet.

Quite clearly, there are many concerns about the United Kingdom model, and there are many concerns within the Australian Government about government business enterprises and about which way the Government should go; but significantly we have played a part in restructuring the macroeconomy and micro-economy in Australia. The Government has gone about that task diligently for a number of years now and, if one examines the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, one finds that effective communications are being provided for the public. Consumers can be well satisfied with the performance of this company. Significant revenue comes from this venture to the Government. It is not a drain on taxpayers' funds and, indeed, the Bill will make it more efficient, more competitive and more effective; but whether or not the Government should go further is something that needs to be considered seriously. It is a great pleasure to support the Bill, because OTC can become stronger and better as a result, and that is certainly something that the Government wants to see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —A series of Bills are before the House this afternoon. They are the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill, the Telecommunications Amendment Bill, the Satellite Communications Amendment Bill and the Postal Services Amendment Bill. As the member representing the people of Maranoa, I wonder why it is that all of these important subjects are debated cognately. I should have thought that the Government would be prepared to debate the Australian National Line, which is a large proportion of Australia's shipping industry, on its own; and I should have thought that it would do the same with the OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, which deals with the large Overseas Telecommunications Commission, and with the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill, which runs at the lovely loss of $50m a year but which at least it is a very large part of our railways system. Telecom is now the biggest corporation in Australia-I believe it now outguns the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP)-so one would think that the Government would be prepared to put even that Bill forward as warranting a separate debate, given the con- tinuing problems with our telecommunications, especially in my part of the world.
—What would happen if we didn't cross-subsidise?

—We will talk about cross-subsidisation and, if we have to charge doctors who live in cities the real price for our food, I know who will be better off. It will not be the city people who are sitting back getting cheap food. The country people are feeding them, keeping them healthy and allowing them to play hockey as well as the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) does. He is an old Olympian and I must congratulate him on his efforts in Seoul. There is no doubt that the doctor and his team did a splendid job on behalf of Australia, but no doubt they did it on Australia's high protein wheat and good beef steaks, most of which would have come out of Maranoa. Of course, some would have come from the Northern Territory. So the guys who sit on their backsides in the big cities of this country and talk about cross-subsidisation have to understand that those of us out in the boondocks doing some work and producing cheap food are using cross-subsidisation as well. Just take that into consideration when talking about who pays for what in this country because, without the country people working their butts off, where would our balance of payments be and where would our standard of living be? They would be down the drain!

SPEECH.PARA: The farmers of this country have saved the Labor Government over the past 18 months with ever-increasing production and with the better prices they have been receiving overseas for the quality products they have produced. Without the help of these farmers, people like the honourable member for Perth would not be able to play hockey and have the opportunity of going to Seoul. Those things should be taken into consideration.

Returning to the subject of satellite communications, satellites on their own would be a sufficient topic for debate in this House. In terms of the postal services, the old PMG is being revamped and corporatised along with Telecom. Most of these instrumentalities were originally set up out of Consolidated Revenue. Her Majesty's mail service was originally paid for out of Consolidated Revenue. It was not an extra tax on the community, as it is today. The trend today in the Labor Party and, admittedly, in our own parties is to move further and further away from the Government and from taxpayers' funding to a corporation. No doubt, the stage has almost been reached where it may as well be sold, because all we are doing now is paying a commercial rate for the use of what were government services which are no longer being supported in any fashion whatsoever by government.

Even under these arrangements, the Minister will still have control over and will still be able to direct the boards that are being established. In view of that, I would like to ask the Minister at the table a question. We did have a Minister at the table, but it seems the Government never wants to govern! There he is; he has moved to our side of the House. I should like to ask the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Jones) why it is that the Governor-General has to become involved in remunerations.

It is amazing how much talk there is in the second reading speeches to all these Bills about the remunerations of the Managing Director and the board members and all the staff and employees, but there is nothing about the cost to the consumers, about what they may have to pay on their telephone accounts or even for stamps from Australia Post. Nothing is said about the poor consumer; but there is a lot of concern about the Managing Director of the board and about going to the Governor-General and obtaining his consent.

It is beyond me why the Governor-General should become involved. I should like to know, legally, why he gets a mention in the Bill. I thought that the Labor Government, after previous experiences of the Governor-General's involvement in government, was opposed to the gentleman. Yet, here he is involved, and the Bill states that board members are to be appointed by the Governor-General! I have never heard of such things. Anyway, that is the way the Government seems to want it, for some reason or another. The Bill also states that the board will consult with the Remuneration Tribunal about remuneration packages for the Managing Director. That would be a great set-up! It is a pity that the Government would not do the same thing for us poor members of parliament. We could continue to consult with the Remuneration Tribunal and get nowhere with our package of remuneration.

The taxpayers of this country must understand that, as we continue to incorporate the postal system, the telephone system, the satellite system, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the railway system, they are no longer services to the taxpayer, but that the taxes the Government is collecting are now being spent on welfare. The Government is continuing to increase welfare spending by huge amounts and, of course, the services like Australian Airlines and Australia Post, which were established to service inland Australia, already involve cross-subsidisation, and so they ought to. No decent company in this country does not cross-subsidise. BHP does it, the Bond Corporation does it-all companies cross-subsidise; they have to, if they are to run their business properly and get complete coverage across the nation. The same should apply to the telephone system.

As I mentioned to the honourable member for Perth earlier, there are many aspects to cross-subsidisation, and it is amazing how it is always the poor inland person who has to be singled out. Cross-subsidisation exists between Melbourne and Sydney and across Brisbane, for instance, with the telephone charges, and so it goes on.

I would like to bring up some concerns from the electorate of Maranoa, and particularly the small community of Hannaford, where I live. We now have cost recovery in Australia Post and Telecom whereby small communities throughout the nation no longer have a post office. They now call these services community services, but there is not much service left to the community; it merely costs the consumers much more money to receive their mail. These people receive their mail only once a week, if they are lucky. The chap who has been running the small post office of Hannaford for 25 years is retiring and Australia Post is taking the opportunity of closing down the post office and offering it out at $1,500 a year as a community service. Nobody in the community is really in a position to run this service for the people of Hannaford, which is only a small district, but there are hundreds of such situations throughout Australia, particularly throughout inland Australia, where we are seeing a continuing drift away from rural areas. Of course, under this Government, that is happening at a much faster rate. There are still people living there. There are still people who have to post their mail and who have to do business.

It is all very well to talk about cross-subsidisation, but it so happens that business is done both ways: it is done inwards and it is done outwards. If a person does not have a phone, it means that BHP cannot get in touch with him if it wants to sell him a few iron posts or whatever. The argument always is that such people are being subsidised for phone calls out from their businesses; but that is not how it works. It just so happens that businesses may wish to contact you, because they are also interested in making a profit and they have to make sales if they wish to stay in business. So, it is a two-way street.

What happened in the small community of Hannaford is a great pity. When the subscriber trunk dialling (STD) service was extended throughout the whole area, the public telephone at the Hannaford post office was removed. Telecom refused to put in a public telephone at the hall, which is a couple of miles away. It is too costly to install a pay phone. We were prepared to install a key phone, but we were told we could not run a key phone because Telecom requires a potential income of $800 to justify the installation of a public telephone. So there is no longer any cross-subsidisation taking place regarding public telephone booths. It is obvious that, despite the taxes they pay, they have been left without a telephone service. The only areas in which public telephones will be installed are areas which will return at least $800 a year. Many small communities are not in that position; there are not enough people in those communities to generate that amount of revenue. Therefore, they go without.

At present, one can travel hundreds of miles along highways throughout these small communities and be unable to find one public telephone box. That is a disgrace. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business should address the problem and, if necessary, provide some funds to supply a community service to these people. It does not apply only to small country areas; it also applies to the outer metropolitan areas of the capital cities of Australia. That is a position many small communities are in, and I draw it to the attention of the House while I am speaking on these Bills.

The next Bill to which I shall refer is the Satellite Communications Amendment Bill. Aussat has been able to sell off space on the satellite, on the transponders, to private enterprise; also, it has sold a lot of space to Telecom and our armed services. Australia now has a satellite system in place, after many years of argument and after much work by the Department of Transport and Communications. All in all, I believe it is working very well. Remote areas of Australia are receiving good service, particularly from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), which has installed small receivers and translators-small dishes to receive the signal and to retranslate those signals to small communities. I am pleased that it has been prepared to supply that service.

On the other hand, there are many small communities that cannot afford a television service, because it costs $3,000 or more to install a single dish and one television set. So not everybody in Australia is watching television. Many areas in my electorate do not have such a service, and they cannot afford to buy a satellite dish. As I said at the time the satellite was launched, it is all very well to give BHP and the steel industry, and General Motors and other motor car companies, a couple of hundred million dollars in government subsidies-buried in what is called research and development but which are subsidies straight out of the taxpayers' pockets through the Consolidated Revenue Fund-simply to keep their business going, but it is different when it comes to people having television through receiving a satellite signal. The Government does not seem to want to become involved in subsidising the aerials. Such small communities have even had a great deal of trouble getting the sales tax removed from the dishes that need to be installed.

Since the satellite has been launched, NQTV has come on stream; at long last remote areas in my electorate are receiving a commercial signal. Most of the areas in my electorate in inland Queensland receive only two signals-one from the ABC and one from NQTV, which is operating on a footprint over all of Queensland and northern New South Wales. We had the absurd situation of an Aboriginal community in Townsville wanting to get involved in the service and take over the television signal. The Aboriginal community has established what we hope will be a good television station in the Northern Territory-Imparja-but it also wishes to intrude into New South Wales, a proposal that I oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The honourable member for the Northern Territory laughs. I am sure the honourable member could not give me any reason why a television station in the Northern Territory should want to send a signal into New South Wales. It is beyond my imagination.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal group in Townsville wants to become involved. It has asked the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to be allowed to broadcast many more Aboriginal programs. The High Court of Australia has rejected one of its applications, which is good. Opposition members are not opposed to the Aboriginal community becoming involved. It is already allowed a special amount of time on NQTV, on the commercial signal, under its licence agreement. But it is not happy with that; it wants to double that time. It wants to put directors on the board of the company; it wants to run the company. Yet the Aboriginal community never wants to put money into it. If money is provided for such projects, it is always taxpayers' money.

Imparja is 100 per cent funded by this Parliament. I guess it is training a few people in how to use television cameras and so on. I wish Imparja well. I guess if we keep pumping money into it it will survive. I do not know when we will get around to commercialising the service. It would be interesting to see the Labor Government introduce a Bill to commercialise Imparja in the Northern Territory.

It has taken me a long time to have a rebroadcast system established in a small place in my electorate, near where I live, called Yellowcap. The residents are still waiting to bring that rebroadcast system on stream. Councils are getting involved. Small communities cannot afford the licence fees. NQTV has installed rebroadcast translators in various towns below a certain size. NQTV was not compelled to install that equipment in towns of less than 1,500 people. Translators have been established in places such as Roma, Cunnamulla, St George, Charleville and Mitchell, as well as other smaller towns in my electorate. There are many other smaller towns like Glenmorgan, Meandarra, Yellowcap, which is a district, Bollon, Thargomindah, Wyandra, Eulo, Quilpie, Windorah, and Birdsville which are not covered by that criterion. In such towns local government has had to install the equipment to receive a commercial signal for the first time.

One only has to look at what the Government is doing to local government. It restricts grants to local government; it has cut back road funding and it has cut back direct grants to local authorities in country areas. Local municipalities are finding it very difficult to help their ratepayers in those small communities. I urge the Minister to take what action he can to see that those municipalities receive the funding needed to help them establish those translators. Every person in a small town cannot be expected to install a dish that costs $3,000. It is different in Sydney, of course. There only has to buy a small television antenna for a few hundred dollars. But a person living in Birdsville wishing to receive a signal has to pay $3,000 for a dish. They are the types of concerns and problems that such people have to put up with because of government legislation.

Finally, I shall refer to the Telecommunications Amendment Bill. Good old Telecom! Overall, it does a very good job. Slowly but surely the telephones in my electorate are being connected to the STD system. This year, Telecom is spending $43m in the Roma zone. Councillors from Roma were in Canberra last week to speak to the Minister for Transport and Communications because of Telecom's policy of centralisation. The Government is placing a ceiling on Telecom's charges and directing it to be more efficient. Nobody minds that, provided Telecom goes about it in the right way. But Telecom is starting at the top and working down. It is moving management from decentralised areas such as Roma, to Toowoomba, which is absolutely crazy. Telecom is spending approximately $45m a year west of Roma to install the digital concentrator system and to continue the installation of cables and STD phones. Most of the constituents in my electorate who live away from the small townships still do not have an STD telephone; they still operate under the old manual telephone system. I have much pleasure in supporting these Bills.
