SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I am pleased to be able to address the House in this cognate debate on a range of Bills dealing broadly with transport, including the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill. It is to that Bill that I would like to refer tonight. Before I do, I would like to commend the contributions of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) and the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney). In particular, I commend the contribution of the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) in outlining to the House the relative merits of having the Overseas Telecommunications Commission looking after Australia's telephonic links on an international basis and comparing the costs of OTC with the costs of similar international agencies. I recall that he used a figure, which may also have been used by the honourable member for Kingston, which demonstrated clearly that the cost of a phone call from Australia to the United States of America was around half the cost of a call from the United States to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing the question of the Australian National Railways Commission Act and the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill 1988, I would like to speak for a moment on the relevance of railways to the Northern Territory. There has been a historic association with railways in the Northern Territory. Indeed, a line which used to go from Larrimah south of Katherine to Darwin and which was closed somewhere in the 1960s, with the stock and the rail being sold after self-government was achieved in the Northern Territory in 1978, was important in terms of Australia's defence capability during the Second World War. It played a significant role in the movement of troops from Darwin south and the movement of supplies and troops north. That line features in a very famous Australian novel by Xavier Herbert called Poor Fellow My Country. I am sure that members of the House will be conversant with that book.

More recently, railways have been important in the context of a proposal to build a new rail link between Alice Springs and Darwin. When the Hawke Government was first elected an offer was made to the Northern Territory Government, after a study commissioned by the Commonwealth into the cost, structure and feasibility of a railway between Alice Springs and Darwin. The Commonwealth offered to contribute 60 per cent of the cost of the construction of that line and asked the Northern Territory to find 40 per cent-not an outrageous suggestion, I would have thought. Unfortunately for many of us the Northern Territory Government, under the stewardship of Mr Ian Tuxworth, the member for Barkly, rejected that offer. When the Northern Territory Government rejected the proposal put forward by the Commonwealth in relation to this cost-sharing arrangement for the construction of a railway Mr Tuxworth said, as reported in the Hansard of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly of Wednesday, 20 November 1985:

My government is left with no option now but to seek to build this railway utilising private ownership, operation and funding. Make no mistake, Mr Speaker, that that is what we intend to do and it will be Australia's first economic railway.

That statement was made on Wednesday, 20 November 1985; yet we are still to see any tangible evidence that the Northern Territory Government has been able to secure private backing for this railway. It leads one to question the irresponsible way in which the Northern Territory Government initially rejected the offer made by the Hawke Government for a 60:40 cost sharing arrangement for the construction of that rail link.

That offer is important in a number of areas: firstly, it demonstrated the concern of the Commonwealth that the Northern Territory should accept a fair share of the costs and, secondly, it indicated the belief by the Commonwealth that such a railway would be appropriate. Unfortunately, with the Northern Territory Government's rejection of this proposal for cost sharing, we are yet to see this railway under construction. I for one am a bit of a fan of the railway and I believe that there are a number of reasons why such a railway would be important. I hope that the Northern Territory Government, having basically thrown away the opportunity offered by the Commonwealth to provide a substantial input of Commonwealth funds into the construction of such a railway, will be able to get private support from entrepreneurs to establish that rail link between Darwin and Alice Springs.

The aim of the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill is to provide for the expansion of the scope of business activities that the Australian National Railways Commission will be able to provide. As part of it, in future the Government will be less involved in scrutinising other activities of Australian National (AN). Instead, the Government will focus on planning through corporate plans, financial targets and accountability of results. Significantly, day to day controls are to be removed in line with this approach and AN will be free to engage in such standard business practices as entering into contracts and normal investment arrangements without the requirement for prior ministerial approval. Borrowings will also be freed from specific approval requirements, subject to continued overall Loan Council scrutiny. This is seen as important as, apart from anything else, it will remove many of the present constraints which provide bureaucratic limitations on the way in which AN operates.

We are all aware that the transport and communications infrastructure forms the very fabric of our economy. Without it, industry could not function, our exports could not reach their markets and service industries, such as tourism, could not develop. I have said previously in this place how important tourism is to the Northern Territory economy. Places such as the Northern Territory would remain isolated and estranged from other parts of Australia and the world. They are areas which have traditionally had a high public sector involvement, partly because they provide essential social services and also because, in some instances, they were not viewed by the private sector as profitable forums for investment in the early days of economic development.

The Government has played and will continue to play a vital role in this area. It is a role that has come under some scrutiny in recent years and it has been an area of rather intense debate. This debate has been of particular importance and interest to those of us who reside in the Northern Territory, where the public sector is the main economic actor, accounting for some 26 per cent of total Territory product and 42 cent of wage and salary employees. Those figures are from the Northern Territory Government Budget Paper No. 6, 1988-89.

In response to the debate about the importance of the public sector and the need for a review of the performance of some public sector enterprises, the Government has introduced a program of reform in that area. The main plank of the Government's economic strategy has been involved with the reform of government business enterprises. The amendments to the Australian National Railways Commission Act which are being debated tonight are part of that reform package. They will continue the process which the Government has set in train to increase the efficiency of the public sector, reducing its demands in the Budget and aiding the efficient operation of government.

The reforms are aimed at improving the flexibility of Australian National (AN), so that it has an increased ability to respond rapidly to changes in the marketplace, and to take up opportunities as they present themselves. They continue the changing relationship between government and business enterprises from a relationship which involves government control to one which necessarily and appropriately demands accountability by business enterprises. Day to day controls are to be removed so that AN, in this instance, will be free to engage in standard business practices, such as entering into contracts and normal investment arrangements without the requirement for prime ministerial approval. As I have already said, the consequences will be a more efficient public sector, including a more efficient AN. These consequences will flow through the economy thus improving competitiveness.

The Australian Government has been involved in the operation of a rail system since 1917 when the Trans Australia Railway was completed and the Commonwealth Railways was established to run the system. The Australian National Railways Commission was established in 1975 and took effective operational control of an amalgamated system comprising the former Commonwealth, Tasmanian and South Australian-although in that instance non-metropolitan railways only-systems in 1978. In 1983 the Australian National Railways Commission Act was passed, providing the national rail system with modern legislation more appropriate to AN's role as a business undertaking with commercial goals. The changes introduced in 1983 have done much to put AN on a more commercial footing. AN's call on the Budget has fallen by more than 60 per cent in real terms, from $106m in 1982-83 to $54.9m in 1987-88. It expects to break even on its commercial operations in 1988-89.

As most people are probably aware, in the Northern Territory there is one stretch of rail, which I spoke of earlier, which is currently utilised by Northern Territory residents-to wit, the line from Adelaide to Alice Springs. This line carries the very famous and romantic train, the Ghan. This is operated by AN and that organisation has introduced some important innovations to increase the attractiveness and, indeed, the romanticism of travel on the Ghan. For example, a conference car has been built which has audio-visual and lecture facilities. There is also a new entertainment car which has been designed to help AN compete with road traffic on the route from Adelaide to Alice Springs. As one who has driven that route on a number of occasions, I might say, as an aside, that travel by rail is far superior. There is not much joy in driving down a straight highway for 1,800 kilometres, I can tell honourable members. These innovations have been particularly successful so that the Ghan is very close to being an economically viable operation. It is certainly worthwhile to run and AN is currently in the process of spending a couple of million dollars refurbishing the train. In the 1987-88 financial year it carried close to 30,000 passengers. AN has established a travel centre in Adelaide to promote package tours, including a rail component to the NT, and to encourage Alice Springs and the Northern Territory as tourist destinations.

The amendments before us tonight, in conjunction with the previous legislative changes, pave the way for similar developments in promotion and targeting from within the Northern Territory itself. They also pave the way for AN's expansion into coach travel which, as anyone who has been to the Territory would know, is a vital and growing mode of transport in our economy. One has only to drive from Alice Springs to Uluru and see the number of coaches that line up at the sunset viewing strip close to Uluru to realise the importance of coach transport in the contemporary tourism industry.

Freight services are also of a major importance in the Territory, as only a small percentage of our product is produced locally and we are heavily reliant on the transportation of a wide range of commodities into the Territory. In the area of freight the central corridor and, in particular, the railhead to Alice Springs, which is then supplemented by road transport to Tennant Creek, Katherine, Darwin and other places, is the most heavily used route for freight transport. Ninety per cent of the freight into Alice Springs is carried by the rail-road link. Fifty per cent of the Northern Territory's freight comes through the rail-road link. AN has worked to improve this corridor with improvements to the track, equipment and train speed. In Adelaide AN operates the Islington freight centre and there is a similar but smaller freight handling depot at the railhead in Alice Springs. The Northern Territory provides wide potential for the expansion of AN's freight services and these amendments, which build on the Commission's ability to undertake a broader range of commercial activities, are important for the Territory and for the increased efficiency and expansion in private enterprises.

AN has for some time now been engaged in piggy-back arrangements with road hauliers, where semi-trailers are transported on the train to Alice Springs and then continue their journey up the Stuart Highway by road. It has also developed a new wagon called the five pack so that more freight can be carried faster and is selling these five packs to private customers. The way is now open for AN to become involved in road freight transport and to expand government freight services throughout the Northern Territory. It is now encouraging greater use of contain- erisation and the way is open for AN to establish a freight handling depot in Darwin and contract arrangements with shipping lines for freight transport. This is not to say that AN will immediately take up these options, but the legislative change introduced by this Government means that, if commercial opportunities arise in these areas, AN is equally positioned with other commercial enterprises to be able to take hold of those opportunities.

Rail has always been a major means of transportation in Australia. It is gratifying to see the increased development and expansion of AN. I commend these amendments to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In conjunction with the 1983 legislation, they add to the flexibility and commercial viability of AN, giving Australia the efficient and effective public transport system that it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to debate the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill and support the honourable member for the Richmond (Mr Blunt) in his amendments to that particular Bill. The Opposition has no concern about the general thrust of the Bill, but we contend that the Government has not gone far enough in privatising the Australian National Line (ANL). The proposition of the Bill is that the ANL have more commercial flexibility, provide corporate plans and financial targets and pay dividends according to the requirement of the Minister for Transport and Communications. That will be an interesting problem-that the Minister will dictate the actual profitability levels of the ANL according to the legislation. I am also pleased to note that the legislation requires that the ANL will revalue its assets every five years, which will give a more meaningful result in terms of economic performance.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill brings about the conversion of the $196m of capital to $1 shares with the Government remaining the main shareholder. I noticed earlier in the debate that the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) supported the privatisation concept so strongly put by the Opposition. He indicated that on various occasions he, like the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and a number of other members of the Australian Labor Party, supported privatisation. However, they have been put off by certain arguments of the left wing and others within the Australian Labor Party, and of course the privatisation argument is now on the back burner. We in the Opposition suggest that the ANL privatisation could be a symbol of what could be done with a corporation and operation which is now totally owned by the Government and which has a monopoly. If we privatised that operation we would then bring more competition into this whole area of interstate sea transport, we would see true competition with road and rail, and we might even achieve transport costs comparable to costs overseas. Of course there would be considerable savings in the capital input by taxpayers, it would help exporters provide a more efficient service, and of course the manufacturers around Australia would be encouraged to find a better coastal operation.

Coastal shipping services have been plagued for many years by the work practices that I will refer to later in this speech; by a total monopoly of the operation with tacit government support; by government regulations covering every aspect of this particular trade; by trade union dominance in terms of both conditions and pay and salary rates; and by capital invested and continuing investment from time to time as the operation becomes more difficult and makes less profit and provides less service. The efficiencies of sea, rail and road transport are very difficult to compare even as the efficiencies of the coastal trade become more evident. So there arise some inequalities as customers move from road to rail and away from coastal shipping because of the various problems they encounter at the container wharves and elsewhere on the waterfront. Of course coastal shipping should be handling the bulk materials such as fertilisers, grains, chemicals and other heavy commodities such as coal and iron ore. ANL has a monopoly over container and bulk shipping, those two areas which should be efficient and the facilities for which should be updated. Of course there is a combination of reasons for the shipping company, the wharf operators and the stevedoring companies not increasing the efficiency of their industry and introducing new technology in container and port practices.

It is interesting to observe the history of ANL. In 1983 ANL lost $18m. At that time it had 33 vessels and employed 3,802 people. I am pleased to say that in 1984 it recorded a profit of $3.3m, and continued to make a profit in 1985, of $41m, with a $38m profit in 1986. But in 1987 its profit was reduced to $14m. I notice that it reduced its number of vessels from 33 in 1983 down to 17 and that there was a change in the type of vessel. However, the number of employees was not reduced accordingly and in 1987 ANL still had 2,738 employees on its books. Whilst there was an improvement in profitability, the number of personnel was not really reduced. Of those employees, 38.4 per cent are engaged in terminal stevedoring work whereas 42 per cent are actually out on the sea undertaking ship activities to maintain coastal operations.

Over time there have been a number of reports submitted indicating the difficulties that coastal shipping has encountered. As many members of the House have reported, the Industries Assistance Commission has been putting forward reports over the past 10 years indicating all the difficulties that coastal shipping has encountered. For instance, the fertiliser industry has had great difficulty, with the monopoly position of ANL, in transferring phosphate rock from Nauru and Christmas Island, and farmers have historically been disadvantaged by up to $20m because of this monopoly position. The transport of iron ore from Whyalla to Newcastle has been dominated by the monopoly position of ANL.

There have been reports concerning the transport of chemicals, and the Economic Planning Advisory Council has produced a report, as have the Australian Manufacturing Council and the Bureau of Industry Economics. They all indicate the very high cost of coastal shipping and the unreliability of the vessels moving around the Australian coast. It is estimated in these various reports that the cost is in the vicinity of $250m to $550m a year. It is estimated that it costs 20 to 25 per cent more than average shipping costs around the world to move shipping around the Australian coastline. Of course this affects those exporters who use shipping for the delivery of bulk materials, and it is estimated that in Australia 30 per cent of the cost of delivering bulk commodities is taken up by shipping costs.

Many members of the House would be aware that the cement industry is now facing a bit of competition from overseas. Some of the new technology in the transport of cement from some of those countries with low production costs has certainly put a bit of pressure on the home industry. The new technology employed in the handling of these cargoes has certainly drawn the difference between the very high costs of the intrastate trade in Australia when we compare the costs of cement companies in Tasmania and New South Wales with the price of imported cement from foreign competitors. The Business Council of Australia has had a good look at the coastal shipping problem and it has put forward a positive plan that there should be some foreign competition to give a true costing of the Australian shipping industry; there should be a reduction in costs; we should have a change in industrial relationships between the management and the staff; and of course the ownership of ANL should be addressed.

In regard to foreign competition, the honourable member for Richmond supports in his amendment the view that shipping from Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries should be allowed to compete with ANL so that we do get a true benchmark of the costings involved on our line compared to the costs of the more industrialised countries. It is worth noting that Japan, Norway and Germany have manning levels about 25 per cent less than we have in Australia. So they would be able to compete, and it should be borne in mind that they have similar standards of living. Foreign competition should make sure that the quotas and regulations that now restrict any competition for coastal vessels should be removed. Likewise, the Business Council suggests that subsidies to ANL should be visible if it is to receive subsidies to allow it to compete with other nations. There should be no hidden subsidies that the taxpayer and commercial community cannot observe out in the open. Of course, I concede that the specialty vessels that move around Australia items such as iron ore, fertiliser and grain do need special attachments.

Moving on to costs, the Business Council suggests that repairs, port dues and handling charges could be reduced. Of course, if we look at the problems of the Williamstown Dockyard we can fully understand the horrendous costs that can be incurred for any shipowner who wishes to repair his ship in Australia. The Business Council suggests, in relation to costs and productivity, that in Australia we have a very high cost of manning ships in our coastal waters, and that that constitutes about 20 to 40 per cent of operating costs. Along with the coalition, the Business Council is suggesting that ships' companies should negotiate agreements that work out terms and conditions and rates of pay that are commensurate with the conditions prevailing at the moment. We have a very competitive world trade situation and a glut of shipping, and Australian shipowners and seamen working in Australian waters should negotiate agreements and working conditions that are compatible with profitability. I am pleased to say that that is in line with the coalition's industrial relations policy. We advocate voluntary agreements between management and staff so that both sides are better off and jobs are maintained and created.

In regard to the repairs and maintenance to which I have referred, it is suggested that it costs 60 per cent more to repair a ship in Australian shipyards than in overseas ports. A number of shipowners have avoided coming to Australia because they know there will be hold-ups. They understand that industrial problems are prevalent in Australian shipyards, which is exemplified by the activities of the painters and dockers union to which I have referred.

Over the last couple of weeks I had the privilege of looking at the Hyundai shipyards in South Korea. They provide a magnificent example of a modern nation prepared to compete world wide. There are 23,000 workers in those shipyards and they work six days a week. They employ great skills across a range of activities. I have no doubt that there are no demarcation disputes in those shipyards because they are keen to get on with the job and create quality output on the many and varied ships that are constructed in those yards. They are competitive on a worldwide basis. It provides a lesson for Australia in what can be done in the area of repairs and maintenance in shipbuilding, if one puts one's mind to it.

There is no doubt that we have a number of inefficiencies in our container ports. The Business Council of Australia suggests that we could improve our efficiency output by 50 per cent. We have modern cranes, container terminals and tracts of land. A change of attitude by staff members and management would improve these container ports quite dramatically so that they are comparable to other container ports around the world.

The coalition suggests that ANL be sold. To date, $160m has been allocated to ANL. It is showing a return of 4 per cent. It is estimated that $250m would be needed to modernise ANL so that it can compete with overseas shipping lines. Another observation that I make concerns the very poor situation in our coastal ports which is a result of a combination of the shipping monopoly, trade union power and restrictive work practices that have occurred in Australian ports over the last 20 years or so. It would be a joke, if it were not so serious, to observe the number of restrictive work practices that have taken place on our waterfront over the past few years which have inhibited the efficiency and profitability of these vital ships which have been held up in exporting our commodities around the world.

For the information of the House I would like to list a number of restrictive work practices which draw home to the public the difficulties that the port authorities are having in introducing new technology and work practices that, by any standards, would be reasonable. Some specific instances are: `nick off' days, where members of a gang draw straws to see who can return home for the day on full pay; more sophisticated variants on the theme are published rosters and auctioning of entitlements. Fifty-four foremen and supervisors are employed at Newcastle for the 186 waterside workers employed at the port. There is certainly a good ratio of foremen to men on the job! In Wyndham in Western Australia 30 Waterside Workers Federation members average eight hours work a week. In another instance the Waterside Workers Federation insists on two members-one on board the vessel and one on the dock-watching while a crane driver and a truck driver move a container from the truck to the vessel; neither is necessary but, because there are two, a supervisor and foreman are also needed. Similarly, two unnecessary employees observe wheat being poured into the holds of a vessel.

In another instance, as a result of union pressure a gangway watchman is engaged 24 hours a day when a vessel is in port, although no work needs to be done, or alternatively the job could be done by a crew member. Waterside employees receive a number of particular allowances for unpleasant work, such as dirt money, stooping money, rain money and cold money. Employees on a night shift frequently work for a short time and then draw straws to see who will remain to clock off all members of the gang, while the remainder go home. Container handling rates in Australia are typically half or less than those overseas. Australian grain terminals handle approximately 14,000 tonnes per employee per year, whereas northern American terminals average 60,000 to 120,000 tonnes per employee. The final instance I give is that overmanning is rife amongst tug operators, as it is with coastal ships.

This is a blueprint for privatisation-converting ANL to a company and then selling the shareholdings back to private investors so that true competition will prevail. The Prime Minister has been advocating privatisation. Of course, the Treasurer advocates privatisation from time to time, depending on the political temperature and activities of the left wing. Even the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is advocating privatisation for those various activities which he knows will be a drain on Government funds. Privatisation of ANL would ensure that there are no future subsidies. It would help the commodity exporters of Australia who make up 50 per cent of our export income. It would also help to to change attitudes and make the Australian shipping line a more commercial activity. It would help in that very difficult area to which I have just drawn the House's attention-industrial relations on the waterfront. If we could privatise ANL we might bring about some changes in the stevedoring industry. Profitability, attitudes, and good work practices might engender quite a big change in this whole area which is so vital for Australia's exports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on the fact that the Government has, as a consequence of the determination of ministerial responsibility, lumped together a number of Bills which involve an enormous area of responsibility. I believe that it is quite inappropriate that we should be debating cognately those matters that are listed on the business sheet. This limits the possibility of identifying the real problems, the real issues and the real consequences of the legislation that is before us. I will content myself with referring to the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1988 because in the time available one cannot hope to refer to all the other issues that are before us.

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of telecommunications, there has been a conscious decision on the part of the Government to proceed very rapidly with what is commonly referred to as privatisation. Under the umbrella of this very broad concept of privatisation, we find an enormous range of determinations with regard to what for so long has been a very important element of service to the community by an instrumentality that has meant so much to the individual and to business, across the whole spectrum of progress and development of our nation.

I have looked at the words expressed in the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). It encompasses an enormous aspiration to carry forward the great charter of Telecom Australia, to carry forward the aspirations of that service and all that it means. But if we look at the fine print we discover that there is a great deal to be concerned about. The first aspect that one discovers is that Telecom wants to serve the community but in so doing wants to meet the wishes of the Government in office. Those wishes are reflected first of all in the undertaking that there will be no disruption to the staff of Telecom. I commend that.

The Bill then goes on to say that there will be an acknowledgment of the consumer aspect of Telecom and I commend that. But let us look at the historic background of the services of Telecom to Australia, which previously operated under a different charter and a different name. Telecom was the flagbearer of what was the Postmaster-General's Department. It was that Department's area of profitability and success. I am appalled that it is being absorbed in the way that it is into just one more compromised public organisation. I say `compromised' because in the mini-Budget of 18 months ago it was obliged to meet extraordinarily heavy charges. In the last mini-Budget further charges were imposed. Of course, as announced by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) in recent times, increased charges are to be imposed by Telecom. Yet the annual report released only a few weeks ago showed a continuing enormous profit on the part of that organisation.

Australia is so different from other countries around the world. It is different because of the vast distances. It is different because of the composition of its communities. It is different because we have an enormous rural area to be serviced by Telecom. It is different because we have on the eastern seaboard and on one or two other fringes of our continent a conglomeration of commerce and industry. If we reflect on what was accomplished by what was previously the Postmaster-General's Department, we can now appreciate that there is an enormous network of the most sophisticated and modern equipment available from around the world. This network provided telecommunications to overcome the backlog that had built up after the cessation of the Second World War. If one sought to make a telephone call interstate or for that matter a short distance within one or other of our States, there was a time delay. People waited not months but years for the connection of telephones.

All of those problems were overcome by modern technology, with the judicious use of funds that were available to Telecom and by the utilisation of profits that it was able to amass. This system was second to none anywhere around the world in providing service to the community. Because of its great success, this Government found that Telecom was an easy target for a source of revenue. So it imposed for government revenue purposes charges which impinged upon the system and the charter that had provided service for so many years.

This legislation is merely part and parcel of carrying through that political decision to utilise Telecom as a revenue earner for the Treasury. I believe that this is wrong. It contradicts all of the historic background of Telecom over so many years. I hope there will be some recognition of this in the determinations that follow this legislation.

Obviously the Parliament will pass the legislation. But I just put it to the Government and to those on the Treasury bench that there is a limit to which Telecom subscribers can be expected to pay the bill. There has been reference in this debate to the decisions to make some changes, for instance, in the bill the subscriber receives. Instead of receiving three or four pages of gobbledegook we will go back to a one-page statement. Why not introduce at the same time something that is comprehended by the Telecom subscriber, by the person who pays the bill? Why not tell the subscriber exactly what the bill is all about? Currently, of course, that does not occur.

Only this afternoon I had a constituent approach me regarding a telephone account. It emerged that, whereas in the past he had received a quarterly account, he now receives a monthly account. Nothing appeared on the statement to say so. There was no notification that there had been a decision by Telecom to issue a monthly account in lieu of a quarterly account. This is just one window into the trend that has occurred. I hope that the management of Telecom will take a strong stand against the Government's intrusion into what it is expected to do for the public and in respect of what Telecom sees as its charter into the future.

Privatisation must, of course, be part and parcel of a recognition of a service that is not in any way, shape or form similar to private enterprise. Private enterprise is one of those areas where the endeavours of the individual, the endeavours of the corporate body, the endeavours of whatever, are dispensed to the public through a private enterprise operation. Telecom, surely to goodness, can never be seen quite in that role. It has a different responsibility. It has a responsibility first of all to the subscribers who pay for a telephone. It has a responsibility to those who over the years have seen Telecom as their lifeline, as their one link with their friends, their business associates, a big corporate organisation, or whatever the modern day technology provides them with the wherewithal to be linked in an effective way through computers or whatever else has been developed in the business sector.

But let us get back to reality. Telecom is there to serve the people. If we impose on it extraordinarily high charges to raise government revenue, if we impose on it a charter that does not take into account the essential element of cross-subsidisation because of distance-a recognition of that very important element in the Australian community; that is, the vast spaces of this country, the vast areas that stretch thousands of miles across the inland and the country areas of this great Australian continent-we are letting down the community that made possible the development of the best telephone system in the world. I appeal to the Government not to go headlong into what can only be described as privatisation without a heart, privatisation without an appreciation of what it really means. Cross-subsidisation ensures that people in far-flung parts of this nation will share the advantages that those in the metropolitan areas have of technology, instant telephone contact and all of the things that flow from telephone contact. This is, without question, a vital matter and one that should not be glossed over, as this legislation proposes to do by saying, `This is your charter. The Government will not interfere. We will appoint a certain structure of management and it will have the responsibility'.

That brings me, in the few minutes still left to me, to the present determination of Telecom Australia to restructure its management and to create certain divisions-a country division and a metropolitan division. What do we find? We find not only State borders being transcended by this new structure-perhaps that is fine; perhaps it is good to have management that can look at the whole continent-but also, when we get down to the locality level, we find that there is a proposition to alter the areas, the regions, of Telecom management as we have known them for about the past decade. I suggest that this could be disadvantageous.

In my own electorate of Page it is proposed that there should be an amalgamation of the Grafton telephone district and two other districts adjoining. Having sought the facts, I find that there is very little to justify the proposition. If it is intended to introduce computerisation for management, accounting and various other purposes, that is good. Let us do it. But why do we have to alter the boundaries to introduce that kind of change?

As to the Government's attitude in this matter, very little has been said by the Government about it at all. I was fascinated to find at the end of last week that the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, issued a press statement criticising Telecom Australia's decisions in respect of changes that would occur in Queensland and saying, `This is no good. I will make representations to the Minister'-the Minister for Aviation and whatever. I do not think the Minister has yet responded to his colleague's public utterance made in an official press statement. If it is good enough for a Minister to criticise the decision that has been made by Telecom in this matter, it is good enough for the rest of us, as members representing various important regions of Australia, to make a similar criticism. I hope that the Minister-whether it be the Minister at the table, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), or his sub-Minister, if we can so term him-will look very carefully at what is being proposed in regard to this aspect of the administration of Telecom Australia. I suggest that the Minister have a good look at what it means.

The Grafton Telecom area in my electorate has a record second to none in the matter of the maintenance of service to every subscriber, a record second to none in terms of early connection for applicants for telephone services and a record second to none in the economics of administration of those services. Matched against other regions, it is a success story in the financial catalogue of what Telecom does. That ought to be recommendation enough. Yet we have superimposed over this vital aspect the proposition that someone knows better and that the boundaries should be changed not only in the Grafton district but also in other districts.

This afternoon the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) referred, as did the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), to the fact, as I mentioned, that a Minister of the Government in office has criticised the proposition for the Maranoa electorate. If it is good enough for that Minister to make a criticism, it is good enough for us to make the point strongly in this debate that these changes are unwise. They have been conceived without proper recognition of the facts relating to the business management of Telecom. It is time to go back to the drawing board and to think again before there is an implementation of the great proposal to restructure the management of Telecom in the regions around Australia.

This legislation is obviously the thin edge of the wedge. The Government would be well advised to think again before it makes the appointments that this legislation would make possible. It should think again about how it moves in the so-called privatisation of Telecom Australia. Telecom provides a service that is worthy of the recognition of this Parliament, of those whom it has served so well over the years. We should not turn the clock back by making Telecom nothing more than a source of revenue collection-nothing more than the tool of those who say, `It is only if the user pays that a service will be provided to the community'. Let us not slip back to what we find even in a developed country such as the United States, where telephone services are not as good as they are in Australia. Australia has a proud record. Let us continue that record by making it possible for every Australian to enjoy the services that Telecom has built up over the years and which it is truly proud of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the House long. This set of Bills-the Australian National Line (Conversion Into Public Company) Bill, the OTC (Conversion Into Public Company) Bill, the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill, the Telecommunications Amendment Bill, the Satellite Communications Amendment Bill and the Postal Services Amendment Bill-might be described as an extremely important set of half-way or part-way Bills. They represent half-hearted efforts by the Government to make some headway in the area of so-called micro-economic reform-what might better be referred to as structural change, or adjustment, and increased market efficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: In the whole complex of policy to promote the economic development of this country, that area of change-structural change and increased market efficiency-is extremely important. In the area of macro-economics, we deal with the great aggregates in an attempt to contain inflation and unemployment. But a key factor in the whole approach to policy is this area, that is, in various ways to increase productivity, reduce costs, thereby enhancing our international competitiveness, and thus address the key, the central, issues confronting our nation of our overseas deficit and massive overseas debt and in that way to begin to set the stage for a rise in living standards.

What we have in these Bills is a pulling back from what ought to be the situation in several cases-for instance, in the case of the Australian National Line-of privatising the whole show, for goodness sake. But we cannot have privatisation, with the left wing of the Australian Labor Party opposing it. That is the problem. It sees privatisation as an ideological issue. It is not. The privatisation we on this side of the House propose is a sensible program of privatisation with a view to increased efficiency and lower prices for consumers. That is what privatisation is all about. It is not a matter of ideology at all. But that is what the left wing of the Labor Party makes it. So we have this half-hearted attempt to go part of the way, for instance, to make the ANL into a public company.

What is required is something in the way of deregulation and increased competition. That is where the benefit will ultimately stem from. Does anybody think this Government would be likely to take on the seamen, which is what is required in the coastal shipping industry, and introduce some competition from other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries? I am not suggesting any sort of sweated labour situation or anything of that type.

What we have in the case of Australian coastal shipping is a situation where it costs as much to ship milk powder from Tasmania to Melbourne as it does to ship it to Taiwan-or indeed more-and certainly as much to ship newsprint from Hobart to Sydney as it does to ship it to Tokyo. That is the sort of situation with which we are confronted. What is required is thorough privatisation along with increased competition.

I cannot stress too much that these Bills, as I said, are a set of halfway or, rather, part-way Bills. They are the best the Government can do in the way of so-called micro-economic reform, in trying to achieve structural change and increased market efficiency. That should be the major thrust of economic policy, yet this Government backs away and brings in these half measures. I understand the time limits that are imposed, so I will not address the House further on this matter. These are potentially very important Bills. They just do not go anywhere near far enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In winding up this long second reading debate, I firstly thank the Opposition for agreeing to a cognate debate on six important Bills. It is unusual to put so many Bills together in a cognate debate, but the issues involved in all of these Bills essentially are similar. I think it was a sensible proposal to have the one second reading debate. I thank the Opposition for allowing that to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: I also thank all those honourable members who have contributed to the debate. There have been a number of very important contributions. I would like to refer in a moment to some of the statements made by Opposition members which I refute. Before doing that perhaps I should refer to what these Bills are actually seeking to achieve. The debate has been very wide-ranging and it is perhaps easy to forget what we are trying to achieve with this legislation. With all of these Bills we are trying to reform various government enterprises-in some cases this is only one of two substantial steps to bring about that reform-in a way which will make them more commercial, more efficient and more likely to operate in a way which will benefit Australians at large more than they have hitherto. Of course, making public enterprises efficient and dynamic is not particularly easy. It is something which various governments have tried to do with varying degrees of success. Some have given up and said, `Let's just privatise them because that is the only way we'll make them efficient'. That, obviously, is the basis of the thinking which lies behind the contributions from most Opposition members.

The Government differs from the Opposition in that it believes we should be trying to ensure, so far as is possible, that government enterprises are substantially efficient, bearing in mind, of course, that in some cases-particularly in the case of Australia Post and Telecom Australia-we cannot simply turn them into straight commercial enterprises. Various members of the National Party would not want us to do that. In the course of this debate they have made the point that these organisations serve substantial social interests and that those social interests should be taken into account by Telecom. Indeed, they criticised Telecom for not taking them into account enough and for being too commercial. So we have some rather conflicting lines coming through in this debate.

In trying to make these enterprises more efficient there are, of course, many difficulties, but we believe that the steps that have been taken in this legislation will provide a very substantial step towards producing more efficient, more dynamic, and more accountable public enterprises than we have had in the past. That is part of the Government's wider approach to bringing about structural adjustment in this country with its so-called micro-economic reform which goes well beyond government enterprise reform and encompasses reform in a number of other areas. The point of doing all of that is to try to make the economy much more productive and efficient, to increase the level of productivity and to enable us to have a more dynamic economy which can better stand on its feet in the international marketplace.

All of the enterprises with which we are dealing today have an impact on our competitive position-some directly and some indirectly. It is substantially important that these enterprises make their contribution to the national need of the time, which is to bring about a more productive and efficient economy than we have had in the past. Of course, Opposition members who in their contributions condemned us for not going far enough did none of this when they were in government. In fact, in the long period in which they were in government in the post-war period, for 30 of the 33 years between 1950 and 1983, they managed to produce an economy which was grossly inefficient and an industry structure which was totally inappropriate to Australia's position in the world which left us massively vulnerable to the adjustment in the terms of trade and left this nation with far less of a living standard than would be the case if much more sensible policies were pursued in industrialising Australia.

With this legislation and other legislation which forms part of our micro-economic reform, this Government is trying to make up for the benign neglect of that long period, that three decades of neglect by the previous Government in which it massively disserved the people of Australia by producing an economy which was entirely on the wrong basis, which had manufacturing industries which were largely, almost totally in most cases, preoccupied with the domestic market and not able to compete internationally. They were not export-oriented and left us with an economy which, as I said, was massively vulnerable to the collapse of the terms of trade. These Bills are part of that process of reforming the Australian economy in a way which will enable it to face up to the world in a much more substantial state in the future than it has been able to in the past.

In the debate various criticisms were made by the Opposition. I will refer to just a few of them for the sake of brevity. It would be quite impossible to deal with all of the comments. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) seemed to be very convinced that we had an abysmal, monopolistic situation which needed remedying. He was so impressed by this thought that he gave us a substantial preview of his speech before he delivered the speech which was relevant to this debate-if it was relevant. His contribution about a monopoly seemed to work on the basis that all of these enterprises were in some monopoly situation. In fact, none of them are in a completely monopolistic situation.

Even Telecom and Australia Post, which have substantial monopoly elements, face considerable competition. Telecom, through the deregulation package which is being implemented, will face considerably more competition in the future. Australia Post already faces competition for something like half of its activities. So even in those areas we do not have a monopoly. In other areas, Australian National Line for instance, it is out there competing. Nearly 70 per cent of what it does is in the international shipping trade. Does the Opposition think that is a monopoly situation? The Australian National Line is out there competing against the rest of the world. On the coastal run it has competition from other shipping lines. There is no monopoly situation there. Even Australian National (AN) with its railway system faces competition from other forms of transport. So I reject entirely the assertion that we have some monopolistic situation. Most of what the honourable member for Mayo said, for that reason, was quite irrelevant.

He also said that AN had sold off its newly acquired locomotives and having done that was leasing them back. My understanding is that that comment is quite wrongly based, that no such action has been taken by AN in relation to its recently acquired locomotives. The Opposition has also criticised AN for not doing enough to improve its efficiency. That was a rather unfair set of criticisms, because AN has markedly reduced its operating deficit since the Government has been in office. It has reduced from a $106m deficit to $55m in the last year, which is roughly a half or, in real terms, a two-thirds reduction in the level of deficit. That must surely be seen as a very substantial increase in efficiency by that organisation, and that improvement in efficiency will continue.

In talking about the railways, one of the interesting things to note is that one sees a conflict coming from members of the National Party, who talk about efficiency, on the one hand, and then, on the other hand, say, `We want railways running all over the place'.

SPEECH.PARA: Suggestions have been made by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) that there is a problem facing the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) in meeting its future capital requirements. OTC is a tremendous success as an organisation. Of course, in a sense, it has a substantial monopoly, given that it is the sole provider of overseas telecommunications-our link with the rest of the world through telecommunications. But, of course, it is facing some competition, increasingly, through other forms of communication-through satellites, for instance. Nevertheless, it is performing very well indeed. Last year its profit was more than $100m. I assure the honourable member for Ryan that it will be able to finance its future capital outlays program, which will be in the order of $2 billion over the next decade, substantially from retained profits. This organisation will be able to meet most of its capital needs from that source and, if it has to borrow, it will certainly be able to do that without in any way engaging in some profligate financial dealing. So we need have no worries about OTC, I assure the honourable member for Ryan.

The honourable member for Ryan also said that government enterprises were sheltered enterprises and were not bound by the Companies Act. He is quite wrong in saying that. These government corporations will be bound by the Companies Act in the same way as private enterprise is, and they will therefore be fully out there on the same basis as private sector enterprises, if they are relevant to their field of activity. The honourable member for Ryan had things somewhat confused. He also indicated in the course of his address that ANL was one of the Government enterprises protected from competition. I have already made the point that ANL is very much facing competition both in international shipping and in terms of coastal trade.

The Opposition spokesman on transport and aviation, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), made his contribution substantially on the issue of coastal shipping. I might say that it was a somewhat irrelevant contribution, because the debate is not on coastal shipping. Nevertheless, he saw fit to make most of his contribution on that issue and has moved a second reading amendment in relation to it. The second reading amendment is quite inappropriate and will not be supported by the Government. The amendment states, in part:
That the House:
(1) notes the failure of the Government to achieve micro-economic reform in coastal shipping and the Australian waterfront; and
(2) calls on the Government to immediately introduce a program to increase the efficiency of coastal shipping, including the introduction of ships from OECD countries . . .

Let me say a couple of things about that. Firstly, in relation to the issue of the failure of the Government to achieve micro-economic reform, I have already referred to the general process of micro-economic reform in which the Government is engaged; and the Government has had active consideration of policy for the two areas of coastal shipping and the waterfront-far more active, I would say, without fear of any sensible denial, than the Opposition had when it was in government. The Government has sought, both on the waterfront and in coastal shipping, to bring about sensible reforms, which obviously has involved difficult issues. That policy consideration process is coming to an end. The Government has reports on both of those issues, one of which is only an interim report in relation to the waterfront, and the Government will, in the course of the next few months, finalise its consideration in relation to both of those issues. So, of course, to condemn us for failure to achieve micro-economic reform when we are in the latter stages of such reform development is quite absurd.

Since the Government has been in office a considerable improvement has been made in the efficiency of coastal shipping, albeit phased in in a gradual way; but the fact is that for all new ships coming into the Australian shipping industry the crewing numbers are far less than those of the ships that they replace, and that is a substantial improvement in efficiency. One can question the pace of development of the reform, but certainly, in so far as that reform is taking place, it is a considerable reform and it can be said without any sensible denial that the Australian shipping industry today is more efficient than it has ever been. In the course of the next few years, even if there were no other change, it would become much more efficient as the much lower crewing levels come into place as a result of initiatives developed by this Government in relation to the industry, through the Maritime Industry Development Committee.

The second reading amendment also refers, as I mentioned, to the need for the Government to immediately open up the coast to the introduction of foreign ships. I must say that I was rather surprised to hear that moved, because it would appear to be quite a contradiction of the previously announced policy by the Opposition in this area. Only a couple of months ago, on 25 August, speaking in this House in the Budget debate, on Appropriation Bill (No. 4), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, in regard to shipping:

Our policy, released recently, directly addresses this issue. We will monitor progress by local shipping companies and the relevant unions in reducing manning levels on Australian ships to levels comparable to those of our trading partners. If we do not receive employer and union cooperation, we will introduce foreign competition on coastal shipping routes, but only as a last resort.

That was said by the Leader of the Opposition two months ago in this House, but in the second reading amendment we have a call for the Government to immediately introduce a program to increase the efficiency of coastal shipping, including the introduction of ships from Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. In other words, the Opposition's policy now, according to the spokesman on transport and aviation, is to immediately open the coast to foreign ships, not to monitor progress-as was said by the Leader of the Opposition to be the policy-and to see whether they could get agreement to increase the efficiency and, if they could not, to then open it up to coastal shipping routes only as a last resort. Apparently that policy has now been overridden by the Opposition spokesman for transport and aviation, but I am not aware of any announcement by the Opposition of the change of the policy, which had been released only a short time previous to the speech on the Budget by the Leader of the Opposition.

If there has been no real change of policy announced by the Opposition, there seems to be confusion among the Opposition about what the policy really is. Opposition members are not sure whether the policy is to do it immediately or after some period of time; nevertheless, they seem to be moving something, in the course of this debate, which conflicts with what the Leader of the Opposition said was the policy a couple of months ago. This is an absurd second reading amendment and the Government totally rejects it.

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 was introduced into this House on 28 April 1988. It is regarded by the Government as high priority legislation which will be of critical importance to Australia's primary industry, to the protection of the health of all Australians and to ensuring the preservation of the Australian environment.

During its passage through this House I agreed to consider seven amendments proposed by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), and have subsequently agreed that the intent of two of these amendments be incorporated into the legislation. The first of these amendments provides for the immediate disclosure of confidential information in the public interest to address a possible or actual emergency. Such situations could arise where recommendations are not followed, in instances of accident or when new pivotal information comes to light. The second amendment establishes mechanisms to handle submissions already in train which have been cleared but not yet registered.

Further consideration by the parliamentary draftsman identified three minor consistencies in the draft Bill which, together with the first two amendments, were passed in the Senate. The function of clearance is to authorise the registration of chemical products by States or Territories. Clause 4 (5) was incorrect in that it referred to `authorising the use of the chemical product'. Reference to the `proprietor' in clause 20 is inconsistent with that used elsewhere in the Bill, where reference is normally made to the `applicant, or holder of, a certificate of clearance'. Complications could have arisen should the proprietor be a different person or body from the `applicant, or holder of, a certificate of clearance'. The amendment of clause 35 removes the possibility of a holder of a clearance certificate refusing the provision of certificates to foreign authorities necessary for export trade.

During the Senate debate the Government accepted further amendments to the draft Bill, namely, substantial increases in the proposed penalties, which were deemed to be insufficient for the severity of the misdemeanours and, in fairness to the holder of a certificate of clearance, a requirement that the holder of that certificate be advised of proposed exports of the chemical product. I believe that this Bill will provide a valuable legislative basis for the current complex regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. I commend the amended Bill to the House and present the consolidated explanatory memorandum.
