TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not opposed to the quite important Budget related Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 before the House. In considering this legislation, I would like to give the House some background, particularly with regard to the last 3 1/2 years of cutbacks and complex changes which this Government has brought forward on veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and indirectly on serving personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is fair to say that one can categorise the area of cutbacks on veterans and so forth into 10 groups. Firstly, in the May 1985 mini-Budget we saw the travel allowance reduced by half to a flat 11.6c per kilometre. This particularly affected country veterans, and there has only been one small increase since that time. Secondly, subsistence allowance, including meals and accommodation, was reduced substantially for veterans-a good deal less government expenditure in this area-resulting in veterans arriving in Brisbane from Kingaroy or arriving in Melbourne from Albury for medical and specialised treatment to find that they were inadequately recompensed for their subsistence during the period that they were required to be in and about the repatriation general hospital system. Thirdly, there have been cutbacks in the dental scheme with four particular categories of treatment being limited to a maximum $300 limit annually with no consumer price index (CPI) adjustments. Fourthly, we have had the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension criteria tightened up and in fact veterans in the retirement phase of their lives are no longer eligible for the TPI. This matter has been partly rectified in this Bill and I will come to that directly.

Fifthly, provisions were made for termination of dependants' allowances by commutation, albeit on a voluntary basis, with no further increase in that dependant's allowance. Sixthly, war widows and their dependants, as well as service pensioners with their fringe benefits, no longer have access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Seventhly, war widows who also receive an age pension will have their social security component frozen at a maximum level of $60.05 with no CPI adjustments. Eighthly, in 1986 a 2 per cent cutback was brought in on Defence Force retirement benefits (DFRB) pensioners. It has not been taken off since, despite the Government saying that it made a mistake in the construction of that 2 per cent cutback. As a consequence, it is compounding. I know my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) will dwell more on this particular matter when he speaks. Ninthly, from 1 January 1988 we have had a $5,000 plus statutory patient contribution imposed on veterans in nursing homes for war related conditions.

Finally, in these 10 big areas of cutbacks imposed by this Government we have had a series of cutbacks in the list of drugs available under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme along with an increase in the number of drugs now requiring prior authority and adding greatly to the administrative burdens. This is the list of 10 areas of significant cutbacks on veterans, war widows and ex-service personnel. Shame on the Government for this treatment of those who served their country in time of war! Whilst there has to be an economically responsible approach to the deliberations of government, particularly with regard to veterans' affairs, veterans' affairs has borne more than its fair share of cutbacks.

This legislation before the House follows on from those 3 1/2 years of cutbacks and complex changes. I think it might be the first tentative step by the Government to recognise that it has meted out some very harsh treatment to many elderly people-to many elderly World War II veterans. To be fair, in this legislation, the Government has brought in some very worthwhile measures and I believe in giving credit where it is due in the context in which it arises.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit late for some of them.

—But of course, as my colleague the honourable member for McPherson says, some of it is too little, too late. During the winter recess I launched the veterans' affairs policy for the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, as it happened on the same day as that magnificent Changi chapel was dedicated at Duntroon. That policy was all about a fair go for veterans. One of the centrepieces of that policy was the introduction of an extreme disablement adjustment (EDA) to cut in at the 150 per cent rate of disability pension for veterans suffering extreme disability in their retirement phase.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy to tell the House and the nation that in its main thrust this legislation adopts the extreme disablement adjustment, patterned on the independent monitoring committee report. I commend that step forward by the Government in introducing the extreme disablement adjustment in the Federal Budget following the winter recess. It is my hope that the veteran will be able to apply for the EDA very quickly-certainly some time after 1 December or very early in the new year. However, I am duty bound to issue a warning to the House that the criteria for eligibility for the extreme disablement adjustment is extremely tight. The lifestyle rating criteria required is six or seven points-not the slightly more flexible five points-and therefore it will be very much a case of veterans with extreme disabilities qualifying for EDA. The Government has budgeted for some 6,000 veterans only to receive this EDA. That should be seen in the context of the tightening up of the TPI pension, which has resulted in thousands of veterans who would otherwise have been eligible not receiving their TPI pension, of course at a saving admitted by the Government of at least $100m a year.

On the one hand, the Government is now providing $3m or $4m by way of this extreme disability adjustment, although we will not know the exact amount until it settles down; on the other hand, the Government is in front by at least some $100m following that savage cutback on the TPI, which was originally launched in May 1985, in the mini-Budget, but was then transferred and set in concrete in the Veterans' Entitlements Act later that year. We have a situation where at long last there is some effort to rectify that TPI anomaly through the provision of the extreme disablement adjustment. To the extent that that is being introduced I welcomed it, but I issue a note of warning: the Government ought to be prepared to review the criteria for the EDA to ensure that it is more comprehensively available to those veterans for whom it was intended.

Another matter dealt with by this legislation is the provision for a reduction from 100 per cent to 70 per cent in the essential eligibility criteria for the TPI pension itself. That, too is in line with the independent monitoring committee report on the Veterans' Entitlements Act. It is also a step in the right direction, and I give credit where it is due to the Government for picking up on this matter in the Budget context. At the same time the Bill provides greater flexibility for the application date and provides for some consumer price index specific adjustments to amputees and other allowances paid under the Bill which are not otherwise covered by automatic indexation. I have had some amendments examined to see whether we could move to switch those particular allowances which require amendments in that annual amending process to an automatic indexation process. Unfortunately those amendments were found to be outside the scope of Standing Orders, and that is to be regretted because I think it is an unnecessarily clumsy approach to have a specific set of amendments to adjust amputees' allowances, other attendant allowances and the other specific allowances not covered by automatic indexation. Surely, above all, those veterans who are amputees should be eligible for automatic CPI adjustment. That is not the case, and I highlight that aspect.

There is another series of streamlining measures in this legislation, but clearly before we proceed to adopt this Bill we have to examine clause by clause the very detailed provisions which cause concern. This I now want to do, because I believe that the House should not be in the business of passing legislation which is deficient in any way, shape or form. The House should be in the business of dealing only with legislation which accurately and comprehensively covers its objectives and it is to be hoped that the Bill will in fact do that. In that context I want to put to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys)-and I am pleased he is in the House tonight-a series of specific matters which I hope he will deal with when he replies to the second reading debate. They are very important matters and go to the detail of this Bill which, I say again, the Opposition is not opposed to. Nevertheless, we want to establish absolutely the effect of some of the clauses and some of the drafting phraseology used in the Bill.

This whole area is still being examined. Perhaps that is partly due to the fact that the Government has not proceeded with the normal consultation that it has extended to, for example, the Returned Services League (RSL) on previous occasions, including in relation to the original Veterans' Entitlements Act. On this occasion we have a situation in which the RSL saw the legislation for the first time when the Bill was introduced onto the floor of the House, and to some extent by that stage it was set in concrete. Whilst there have been briefings and consultations, I think the original undertaking of the Government would have been better adhered to; namely, there should have been earlier consultations so that the Government and relevant veterans organisations could study the Bill in detail to see whether any matters had slipped through. We have just seen in relation to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill, the previous legislation before the House, a situation where the Government had to amend its own legislation because of certain omissions, and I now want to highlight for the Minister a number of matters of genuine concern. To be fair, I think they are concerns held by honourable members and senators on both sides of the Parliament.

I seek an assurance from the Minister that the transitional provisions of this legislation comprehensively cover every situation relating to veterans who have claims in the determining system and that there will be no detrimental situations arising at either Veterans' Review Board (VRB), Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) or Federal Court of Australia level relating to the Bill before this House if it is enacted as it is presently constructed. Those transitional provisions should be watertight. They should cover applications and they should provide a basis for the Federal Court, the VRB and the AAT to make determinations.

Perhaps there is in fact one area where this is not the case. That relates in part to proposed section 24 (a) (i), which the Minister has indicated in letter form will have no adverse impact at all if passed in its present form but which, the Minister goes on to say, may well require some technical amendments. If it is going to require some technical amendments, clearly the legislation in its present form is, by degrees, inadequate. Is that inadequacy, in turn, going to create a situation of a detrimental nature to veterans; a situation where the determining system at VRB, AAT and Federal Court level cannot deal with claims which may already be in the system, may already be the subject of appeal? It is my understanding that, once the date of assent passes, this particular technical transitional anomaly will be covered, but what is not clear is whether it is by any means covered right at this point of time by the construction of the Bill. I seek the Minister's assurance that the transitional provisions comprehensively cover every situation which might arise in the context I have just highlighted.

I turn to clause 10 of the Bill, and refer in particular to the part which deals with the rate or rates at which the pension would have been payable `from time to time' during the assessment period. This is yet another complex area of legal interpretation and I understand that clauses 11 and 12, whilst stated in the negative, have some bearing on the application of that particular phrase. I further thank the Minister for providing by way of letter an assurance that this will definitely mean that claims and eligibility for pension for a veteran for a period from his application date to the time of his final assessment, during this whole assessment period until an ultimate decision is made, will be accepted and payment will be made from the first day of eligibility. If that is so, why not say that in the wording of this particular proposed section? Why not say, instead of `from time to time', something along the lines of `from the first day within the assess- ment period when the veteran becomes entitled to an appropriate level of pension'? That would be an alternative form of wording to the existing phrase. As a consequence of the timing of this debate, I understand the Minister will have an opportunity to examine this overnight and reply in his response to the debate.

The area of concern in clause 10 in respect of disability pension concerns the range 10 to 100 per cent. In a sense, it relates only to the assessment period. It does not impact once the ultimate determination is made. I accept all of those qualifications, but equally, it is important that we know that the first date of eligibility will be the practical reality applying and arising out of this clause and the phraseology at the bottom of page 5 of the Bill. Not every person or organisation associated with the veterans constituency is satisfied of that. One has to rely on some very complex and often conflicting legal comment when examining this matter. It is not a matter which is essential, for example, to the implementation of the extreme disablement adjustment, but it is essential to getting it right in terms of the veteran and making sure that he will be paid from that first date of eligibility. I seek an assurance from the Minister in that second area dealing with the phrase `from time to time'.

The phrase `detained by the enemy' is deleted and the phrase `a prisoner of war' is substituted. This terminology has been sought by Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop, members of the Ex-Prisoners of War Association and other organisations. It is something which those on both sides of the House fully support. Again, we would like to see placed on the record by the Minister that that change, in itself, will not deny any veteran any access to a pension to which he would have otherwise been eligible, or the successful determination of any claim which he would have otherwise lodged.

I turn to the question of the criteria for the extreme disablement adjustment which I have already mentioned. The rating has been set at six or seven points. That is something which the Government will have to look at in light of the practical application of the EDA and those people who will be eligible for that extreme disablement adjustment. The cut-off is still quite severe. The best example is given by taking two World War II veteran brothers, John and Jim, working side by side at, say, Borg-Warner (Australia) Ltd at Albury in my electorate. John suddenly suffers a very sharp deterioration in his war-related lung condition and applies for and ultimately gets the TPI pension. He keeps that pension, which is presently $220 a week, for the rest of his life. A month later Jim retires from work at Borg-Warner, shakes hands with the manager and walks out the front gate. A month later, Jim comes down with exactly the same war-related lung condition. As the law now stands, he cannot get access to the TPI in any way, shape or form, so sharp is the cut-off. At least once this Bill is passed he will be able to get access to the extreme disablement adjustment-or, should I say, he may be able to get access to that adjustment, so tight are the criteria associated with it, I seek a commitment from the Minister that he is prepared to review the criteria after six months of operation to see whether the rating should be shifted from six or seven down to five of perhaps even four points.

I also seek an assurance from the Minister, when he responds to this debate, in relation to the peacekeeping forces. We should be reminded that at the moment there are four groups of Australians in very dangerous places, in the Middle East and elsewhere. There is talk of a fifth group going to Namibia. Of course, until quite recently there was also the Royal Australian Navy diving team. There has not been absolute clarity with regard to the coverage under the repatriation legislation of their widows, should that sad circumstances arise. We must be absolutely sure about these matters. If Australians are sent by the government of the day as part of the peacekeeping force to Iran or to the other three areas in the Middle East, they are entitled to go to those countries with full coverage already in place and already listed in the schedule to the Veterans Entitlements Act. That is not the case; that should be the case. The honourable member for McPherson will deal with the matter in more detail.

I ask the Minister in his reply to the debate to look at that aspect so that the House knows exactly what the position is and so that the service men and women-I totally reject the term `servicer' which the Style Manual would have us use in that context-who are sent overseas can be satisfied about their coverage, with no ifs, doubts or qualifications. It is a matter of record that we are still trying to straighten out eligibility, for example, for the Vietnam campaign medal. The Government, the Parliament and the nation eventually got around to granting repatriation cover retrospectively to those who served on the HMAS Sydney and other support ships between Australia and Vietnam. Nothing was done until three years ago, a decade or more after the end of our involvement in the Vietnam War. That is why it is so important that these matters be dealt with properly.

I have listed five areas of specific concern to the Opposition. They are very important areas to which I invite the Minister to respond comprehensively. I have signified these matters to him in order that he might do so. I hope that he will afford the clarification which is essential so that these matters can be properly determined by the lower House and, likewise, by the Senate. Notwithstanding these areas of concern and the huge number of cutbacks and complex changes imposed by the Government, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. It introduces the extreme disablement adjustment, which is part of our coalition policy; it provides a slightly more lenient basis for qualifying for the totally and permanently incapacitated pension; and it provides a number of other improvements flowing from the Budget and from the independent monitoring committee report.

There is also very widespread concern amongst the veterans constituency over delays in the determining system and over the complexity of the system as it stands today. I mention in that context that justice delayed in justice denied. Many veterans have said to me that they are suspicious that their claims are being pushed back, delayed, adjournments sought and obtained, by elements of the Department in the hope that the veteran will fade into the sunset before a decision has to be made and a pension paid. That is simply not good enough. This is a commitment that the nation owes to those who served their country in times of war. It is a commitment which should be honoured in the way in which Ben Chifley once told this House:
On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.

We know from my list of 10 cutbacks that the right thing has not be done in recent years for the veteran and the war widow. This must be reversed. That is what the coalition policy is all about. We want a fair go for veterans. That is what the Government should be about. Instead, it is taking these tentative steps in that direction and not seeking comprehensively to reverse some of its cutbacks.

Before I conclude my remarks and a Government member rises to speak in this debate, let me say that, for example, we have given a specific commitment to reverse the statutory patient contribution which the Government has imposed on veterans in nursing homes. The Government has imposed it since 1 January 1988-in our bicentennial year. It has imposed it on veterans who are in nursing homes for war-related conditions. It has imposed it at a rate in excess of $5,000 a year. What a bicentennial gift for our World War I and our TPI veterans! That is what has flowed from the Government's 1987-88 Budget. That is what has applied since 1 January. That is what I have given an absolute commitment to alter, in the context of our providing and ensuring a fair go for the veteran, the war widow and our ex-service personnel. In that context I move this second reading amendment that has been circulated in my name:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`Whilst supporting the general thrust of the Bill, the House is of the view that:
(1) repatriation should be recognised as compensation, and not welfare, in acknowledgment of the service of veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel;

(2) there has been a series of cutbacks and complex changes impacting on veterans, war widows and ex-service personnel described as a `penny pinching, miserable and narrow-minded cash-register approach' and typified by:
(a) a $300 limit on certain categories of dental treatment within the one year;
(b) the halving of the country travel allowance for veterans referred to specialists and Repatriation General Hospitals;
(c) the hardship imposed by recent changes in the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme;
(d) the imposition of a statutory patient contribution in excess of $5,000 per year from 1 January 1988 on veterans in nursing homes for war-related conditions;
(e) the massive delays in the determining system, thus denying justice where veterans die before a decision is made; and
(f) the 2% cutback applied to DFRDB pensioners in 1986 which has never been rectified despite promises by the Government to do so; and

(3) the Government should take account of recent criticisms of Government policies, priorities and administration in relation to the repatriation and system and make the necessary adjustments as a matter of priority'.

Indeed, as the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) said, we have had a number of speeches not only from our side of the House but also from an ex-prisoner of war, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), who said that the Government had adopted a penny pinching, miserable, narrow minded, cash register and heartless approach. That sums up the Government's policy on veterans' affairs as perceived and felt directly by veterans. That is partially rectified by this legislation, which the Opposition will not oppose because of the positive though tentative, steps it takes to fix up some of the measures which I have described in the course of this debate.

Equally, we take this opportunity to say to the House and the nation by way of this second reading amendment that repatriation is not welfare; disability pensions are not welfare; war widows' pensions are not welfare; service pensions are not welfare. They are compensation for what those people have suffered in the service of their nation. Let us also see that those who are still serving their nation and facing loss of their life in the Middle East in peacekeeping forces are fully covered in a time honoured way.

At the very least, I hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be categorical in his response to the second reading debate so that these matters are injected into the record and can be utilised by the determining system in relation to the serious queries that I have raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to lead off for the Government in this debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, the latest of this Government's initiatives to improve fairness and equity in the area of veterans' entitlements. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), said at least twice during his speech that he believes in giving credit where it is due. Having worked with him on several occasions, I believe that is his wont. However, perhaps instead of singling out a very selective litany of cuts which this Government has made in various areas, he could have mentioned, if he wanted to give credit where it was due, that this Government has increased funding for veterans' affairs almost 100 per cent since it came to power.

SPEECH.PARA: The veterans' affairs budget under the previous Government in its last year was $2.3 billion. The veterans' affairs budget this year was $4.5 billion-as I said, an increase of almost 100 per cent. As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) pointed out in his second reading speech, this Bill is aimed at giving effect to those recommendations in the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee which the Government accepts. Nine of the 32 accepted recommendations are considered in this Bill. I wish to address myself specifically to three major aspects of the Bill: firstly, the so-called application day provisions; secondly, the relaxed requirements for eligibility for the intermediate and special rate of pensions; and, thirdly, the entirely new payments proposed in this Bill, namely, the extreme disablement adjustment.

I consider that the changes that this Bill makes to the application day provisions are a very important step in bringing more fairness and reason into the system of awarding special rate pensions. Until now we have worked under the rather artificial and arbitrary system whereby a veteran's application is assessed according to his state of health or disability on the day of application; that is, the medical report he received on that day is the only one taken into account during the whole decision making process and progressive or sudden changes in the applicant's physical state are not taken into account. We have conceivably had cases where a veteran may have suffered a severe setback, perhaps a heart attack or simply gradual rehabilitation between his day of application and the day of decision, but where this deterioration was not taken into account when the decision was made.

This state of affairs is particularly serious when, as in the instance of a case coming before the Veterans' Review Board, the delays between application and decision can be anything up to four years. Even in a straightforward assessment by a departmental officer the normal period for assessment is 90 days. Under these new provisions an applicant's state of health can theoretically be assessed on a day by day basis. Certainly the decision making body can review its deliberations whenever further medical evidence comes to hand, either from the applicant's local medial officer or from a hospital or wherever.

The great benefit of this change for veterans will be, firstly, that it removes the onus on veterans to continually lodge applications in accordance with their state of health. The system after the application of this Bill will automatically take these changes into account. Secondly, it means that the end decision will more accurately reflect the veteran's real condition and real need.

The second provision of this Bill that I would like to address is the changes to the criteria for receipt of an intermediate or special rate disability pension. At present, the first of these criteria is that the veteran be receiving or be eligible to receive a disability pension at 100 per cent of the general rate. The Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee had recommended that this criteria be eliminated completely. This, however, we believe is not in accordance with the spirit in which these pensions are awarded. They are intended to compensate in part for a reasonably high degree of incapacity. However, we do recognise that unemployability can be used by factors other than just pure physical disability and that this need not be the only determinant of the applicant's eligibility.

Accordingly the Bill provides for a reduction in the required degree of incapacity from 100 per cent to 70 per cent. The honourable member for Farrer criticised this, saying that this relaxation did not go far enough. Criteria were changed in 1985 when it became clear that the outmoded terminology in the old Repatriation Act was enabling these pensions to be paid to veterans who had completed a full working life. The Committee and the honourable member for Farrer have nevertheless criticised these criteria. They overlook the original intention of the intermediate and special rate pension, which was to compensate severely disabled veterans who could not work on their return from service. I envisage that this provision will be of particular benefit to younger veterans such as Vietnam veterans who under the existing criteria would not rate a 100 per cent disability rating but who would be, nevertheless, deserving for other reasons of an intermediate or special pension.

A major initiative of this Bill is the proposed introduction of the extreme disablement adjustment. Existing provisions exclude from the intermediate and special rate pension those veterans who have passed the normal retirement age and who are precluded by this by continuing in or resuming employment. These veterans are disabled beyond the threshold required for 100 per cent of the general rate but have no avenue for compensation. They would be provided for under the extreme disablement adjustment. It is only fair and just that they qualify for such a payment.

In technical terms the proposal is that recipients of this adjustment must satisfy an impairment of lifestyle rating of six, that being the average of their scores in various categories. The honourable member for Farrer said in his contribution to this debate that he and various ex-service organisations have voiced the opinion that these criteria are too strict. The honourable member suggested, I believe, that they could be reviewed later. This seems to me to be a reasonable proposal. I understand that, if it is found in the future that the target group is not being reached, the criteria will be reviewed. I emphasise that this proposal is important to enhance the fairness of the veterans' entitlements provisions.

The Bill also increases some minor benefits which until now have not been automatically indexed. I commend the Government on this action also. There is one other provision of this Bill which is not a substantial change in that it effects veterans' entitlements but which is, I believe, important in the broadest sense, that is, the restoration of the term `prisoner of war' to denote service personnel who were taken prisoner by enemy forces. In recent times the official term for all people, whether civilian or service, who were detailed by the enemy have been just that-`detained by the enemy'. I understand that the Ex-Prisoners of War Association and specifically, as the honourable member for Farrer mentioned, its President, Sir Edward Dunlop, has been advocating that service personnel detained by the enemy should be officially referred to once more by the term `prisoner of war'. I certainly have no objection to this distinction being made.

I personally have a considerable link with the Ex-Prisoners of War Association. The South Australian President of that Association, Mr Byron Fitzsimmons, is a constituent of mine. I met him quite by accident while doorknocking last year as the Australian Labor Party candidate for Hawker, was immediately invited into his home and spent a very pleasant and informative half an hour with him and his wife. Since then we have kept in touch and meet quite regularly. I am very grateful for his friendship and for any information and opinions which he may have on the situation of ex-prisoners of war in this country.

Even closer to home, my father-in-law, Dr Bill Harvey, a medical officer in the British Army and a prisoner of the Japanese for four years in Changi Prison and on the Burma-Siam Railway, has passed on many of his experiences to me. I am, indeed, one of the few fortunate people who have read his very poignant diary of those years. He subsequently became the medical director of the Repatriation General Hospital at Daw Park in South Australia. Even now, at the age of 85, he is still an active member of the Ex-Prisoners of War Association and regularly attends its conferences in Queensland. So I am very much in favour of any measure which will assist the status and condition of ex-prisoners of war. In this respect I endorse fully the recent statements by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) in respect of our treatment of former prisoners of war of the Japanese. I have nothing further to add to this debate except to commend the Bill to the House. I believe that it rectifies certain omissions in the existing Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to join in this debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey)-and I am sure that she has a genuine concern for veterans-started off her contribution to this debate by saying how well the Government is looking after its veterans because it has increased the Department of Veterans' Affairs budget from $2.3 billion to $4.5 billion. If that is the level of understanding of Government members-that the requirements of the veteran community in Australia are served by increasing the veterans' affairs budget-the mind boggles as to what sort of treatment veterans will get in the future. The reason that the budget has increased is that more veterans are coming into the system and are demanding more and more services. It is not the generosity of the Government that has led to more services being made available.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) detail 10 points where veterans' entitlements have been cut back. The budget has had to be increased because veterans are getting older and their disabilities are getting worse and they are demanding more and more services. We must understand in the context of this debate why the Department of Veterans' Affairs budget is being increased. As I said, it has nothing to do with the generosity of the Government.

Whilst Government members get up and say that they understand what is happening, very few, if any, on that side really understand what is happening in the veterans' community. The honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) made a speech in this House not so long ago. He obviously does understand because, as an ex-prisoner of war, he has very close links with the veteran community.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is on the Government side, isn't he?

—He gave his side a good old serve, which I will get to in a minute. The problem is that, as the years pass, people forget. Not only do they forget but also they do not understand what sorts of experiences many of these veterans went through. Let me give a brief example. A friend of mine who is an ex-prisoner of war went to this local medical officer a couple of years ago for some treatment. He had never seen this local medical officer before. He explained what was wrong with him. The local medical officer said, `How did you acquire those disabilities?'. He said, `I was a prisoner of war of the Japanese'. The medical officer said, `Well, tell me about it'. That is fair enough. The medical officer at least asked my friend what it was all about. He had never heard of my friend's particular disability and wanted to understand how it had happened. At the end of the story, the medical officer said to this ex-prisoner of war of the Japanese, `Now I understand where you were for those years during the war. But you are very lucky that you were out of the war zone for three years and, what is more, you were on a healthy, high fibre diet. So you really should have no complaints'.
—Who said that?
—That was a local medical officer talking to an ex-prisoner of war.
—That is a disgrace.

—I mention that because, amongst some members of the community, that is the level of understanding of the experiences of these people. That attitude, unfortunately, is reflected also in this House, which represents the community. It is very easy to say, `Those wars happened a long time ago. These people are now old and their numbers are declining, but the services they are demanding are increasing'. It is very easy to say, `If we turn a blind eye, sooner or later they will disappear'. It is a tribute to the honourable member for Reid that recently in this House he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I express strong criticism of those Ministers in the Hawke Government whom I have often described as having cash registers for hearts and little understanding or compassion for war veterans or their widows.

I think that is a fairly accurate reflection of the views of some honourable members, particularly those on the Government side. It reflects fairly accurately what the honourable member for Reid believes is the Government's attitude towards veterans and serving personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I digress for a minute to say that the Government's attitude to veterans is reflected in its attitude towards serving personnel. That is why in 1988, in 1987 and in 1986 we have had record losses from the services. The Government does not understand the role of personnel in war. It sees it as a matter of big equipment, big battles, but the personnel are neglected. Month after month in the last three or four years we have had record losses of personnel in the Australian Defence Force because of neglect and disinterest. We have all heard the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) make speech after speech in this House about defence and never once mention the role of personnel in the Defence Force of this country.

INTERJECT.PARA: Let me quickly give some indication of the number of veterans we are talking about. In the Boer War 16,000 Australians served; in World War I, 336,000 served; in World War II, 557,000 served; in Korea, 16,000 served; I do not have the figures for Malaya and Borneo but I would think probably 20,000 served; in Vietnam, some 50,000 served. There have never been, to my knowledge, any other group of Australians who were subjected to such treatment as prisoners of war. It is perhaps the case in Europe, but I am not familiar with that. The veterans ask: Where are the Government's priorities? In the last few years $30,000 or $40,000 have been spent on supporting the gay mardi gras in Sydney, and the veterans ask: Where are the Government's priorities? Recently we had a spectacle of arts grants. Money was given for a study on motherhood--
Mr Humphreys-I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. None of this has anything to do with the Bill. I ask you to bring the honourable member back to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister that there is an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill and if he cared to refer to the points made in that amendment he would find that the honourable member for McPherson is in order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr WHITE

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is no need to draw your attention to the second reading amendment. My remarks are pertinent because we are talking about priorities. We are talking about priorities of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Taxpayers' money was spent on the study of motherhood and ancient Rome. A grant was given to women surfboard riders so they could find a lower centre of gravity. I think that was the subject of the study. Artists in residence have been funded. The State trades and labour councils have been funded. We had the recent spectacle of the appointment of a new Governor-General who is wandering around the world on, I think, his fiftieth trip spending $80,000 of taxpayers' money. Extra politicians have been foisted on this House by the Hawke Government. We have the easy unemployment benefits. We see people who will not work because the test is not tough enough. I am not talking about the genuine unemployed. Any day in my electorate I can find hundreds of people who will not work. They are out there on the beach and in the surf every day. The veterans ask: Where are the Government's priorities? That is the point I make. It is a matter of fairness and equity to those who have served their country. They also ask where are the Government's priorities in trying to preserve all the things they fought for. They remember when, in 1983, an allied warship-the Invincible-came to this country, was not allowed to dock in Sydney, and was sent away to Singapore. An allied country would not repair the ship, and the veterans ask: where are the Governments priorities?

INTERJECT.PARA: Two or three weeks ago a similar incident occurred when the HMS Edinburgh came to this country. It required repairs, but when it arrived in Sydney we said, `Sorry about that, the union said no. The Government buckled under; you will have to go and find your way back to England on one propeller'. No wonder the veterans question the Government's priorities.

There are some good amendments in the Bill and, as the honourable member for Farrer has indicated and acknowledged, it is about time they were made. Those who could not receive the totally and permanently incapacitated pension before because they were not 100 per cent on retirement will now have more easy access to it. That is something for which we give credit, because it is grossly unfair for someone who retired with a war caused disability for that disability to be held against him, because it was not recognised before he retired, for the rest of his life. Therefore, that is an excellent measure. The acknowledgment that a man's or a woman's condition deteriorates after the lodgment of his or her claim is a step in the right direction.

In conclusion, probably in the next few months, the claim will be forthcoming from the Ex-POW Association for reparations from Japan. That is a contentious issue. I certainly do not speak for the Opposition in any way on this point, but a lot of the activity on that matter has been generated in my electorate. I have met with the people who feel very strongly about it. Not all veterans feel the same way. The matter should be closely examined, discussed and decided upon. There is no doubt that the German Government paid reparations to people who had been held in German concentration camps. I am not sure of the detail but, so far as I know, no reparations have ever been paid to Australians or anyone else held in Japanese prisoner of war camps.
Mr Lee-What about German POWs?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr WHITE

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure. But what I am saying is that this is an issue which, for one reason or another, has been pushed aside for more than 40 years and that it will now come to the fore. It deserves support for examination and then, eventually, for a decision to be made.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Air Marshal Sir Harold Martin-Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome-Methadone Programs-Anzac Ship Project

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Humphreys) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to an outstanding Australian, Air Marshal Sir Harold Martin, who died last Thursday at his home in London. Harold `Micky' Martin was born in Sydney in 1918. As is often the case with remarkable people, hurdles placed in their way which would discourage many others serve only to reinforce their determination. So when Harold Martin was told that, because he was an asthmatic, he could not pursue his love of flying in Australia, he looked for opportunities elsewhere. He went to England. It was wartime. As the threat to Britain from a determined and daring German Luftwaffe increased-and with it the list of casualties from the ranks of the Royal Air Force (RAF)-conditions such as asthma became minor considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: `Micky' Martin first saw service with an Australian Hampden bomber squadron operating with the Royal Air Force. In 1942, whilst serving with an RAF Lancaster bomber squadron, he was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross (DFC). Before the war was over he was decorated twice more with the DFC-the Royal Air Force's highest award for bravery in action. In 1943 he transferred to the RAF's 617 Squadron. This was the squadron which came to be known throughout the world as the Dam Busters-the brave and youthful airmen given the responsibility of dropping Barnes Wallis's equally famous bouncing bomb in the daring raids over the Mohne, Eder and Sorpe dams in Germany's Ruhr Valley industrial area. For the bouncing bombs to have any chance of being effective, the planes had to fly about 60 feet above the water against heavy concentrations of German anti-aircraft fire. Anyone with any experience of low-level flying will appreciate the skill and courage needed to bring a heavy bomber to within the limits required for the success of this mission.

On 16-17 May 1943 Harold Martin flew one of 18 Lancaster bombers on a night raid over the Mohne Dam. His plane became a target for German anti-aircraft guns and was hit by exploding shells during the bombing run. Despite the damage his Lancaster sustained, Martin completed his mission successfully and was able to nurse his plane safely home. Although the raid did not totally achieve the expectations of massive and irreparable damage to the dams-and thereby to the German war effort-it was recognised as one of the outstanding flying feats of the Second World War, and those who took part in its planning, and more particularly in its execution, were immortalised in the post-war film and book The Dam Busters.

`Micky' Martin continued his distinguished wartime flying career, developing a reputation as a skilled low-level flier specialising in night time attacks on enemy airfields, and dropping flares to illuminate targets during heavy bomber raids. After the war Sir Harold pursued an outstanding career with the RAF. He was awarded the Britannia Flying Trophy in 1947, and in 1963 served as aide-de-camp to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II. In 1970 he was promoted Air Marshal, and was appointed Commander-in-Chief of the RAF in Germany and Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation's Second Tactical Air Force. He served with distinction in these posts for three years. Sir Harold `Micky' Martin is survived by his Melbourne-born wife, Wendy, whom he married in 1944, and two daughters. He was a true hero, a daring flier, an honourable and gallant man, and a very great Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is, perhaps, one of the most fascinating medical problems we find ourselves faced with this century, but it is also a problem of frightening magnitude. Within the community a number of high risk groups exist. Homosexuals, intravenous drug users, and those who require the use of blood products are among those in the high risk area.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great concerns which the Government faces and about which all Australians are concerned is that the disease, which is found predominantly in these high risk groups at this stage, will find its way into the heterosexual population. Indeed, there is really no opportunity for us to wait and see what happens. This is a disease without cure and therefore it is necessary, in many cases, for us to indulge in perhaps what might be seen as radical solutions.

One of those solutions was suggested last week by the National Health and Medical Research Council, and the proposal is that heroin be made available for AIDS victims who are intravenous drug users. The belief, of course, would be that, along with the methadone program which presently exists for such people and needle sharing programs, this would be a further block to the spread of AIDS within that community and, therefore, into the heterosexual community. Clearly, it is a controversial suggestion, but one that certainly needs consideration; and it was my hope that the Government would take up this program, because we need to start to do some radical things in this area.

If one examines overseas figures one finds the frightening fact that in Edinburgh in the United Kingdom 65 per cent of intravenous drug users are AIDS sufferers and that in New York the figure is more like 85 per cent. Those are frightening statistics and clearly ones that should concern us in this country. In Sydney, the figure presently sits between one per cent and 3 per cent. I would hope that by preventive measures and by the implementation of what is seen as a radical program we would be able to continue successfully to control the disease in the way that we are aiming to.

When one talks about drug abuse, one faces a larger problem. Recently I read an article in the Canberra Times by Joan Morris, who had just returned from Holland with some interesting insights into the drug problem. We have a hypocritical attitude towards drug abuse in Australia. Clearly, the drugs of greatest addiction are alcohol and tobacco. The motivation of those who sell those substances is no different from that of drug traffickers. Yet there are completely different sanctions on those people. I suppose those are historical and cultural differences, but we must realise that our attitudes are hypocritical in that respect.

In my view, the Dutch have a much more relaxed and sensible attitude to the problem. They do not try to hide the problem and nor do they try to overemphasise it. I shall quote from the article, which refers to the attitude of the Dutch:

``Prevention should therefore eliminate the fascination with, and misplaced idealisation of, a user. The phenomenon of drug use should be shorn of its sensational and emotional overtones . . . being a `junkie' should be demythologised and deglamorised''.

To this end, the policy is for ``normalisation''-drug takers and even addicts should ``neither be seen as criminals nor as dependent patients, but as `normal' citizens of whom we make `normal' demands and to whom we offer `normal' opportunities'', Mr Engelsman said.

Addicts should not be treated as a special category, except when necessary. The Dutch are concerned with the health hazards arising from drug abuse, but feel this concern should not be accompanied by exaggerated attention.

The statistics in Holland are quite impressive. Between 1981 and 1986, the average age of drug users in Holland increased by two or three years. Between 1981 and 1986, in Amsterdam, which has a massive drug problem, the use of drugs by people under 21 years of age fell from 14.4 per cent to 5.1 per cent. Clearly, in that country, a more liberal and perhaps pragmatic attitude to drug use has been very successful. Of course, that country has significant methadone, needle share, and heroin supply programs, which are perhaps much more enlightened than programs in our country. As a result, we see an increasing number of people--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 November in this place, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) highlighted the importance of the multibillion dollar Anzac ship project, not only in respect of its critical operational implications for our Navy, but also as an ingredient in the very necessary ongoing development of the nation's industrial infrastructure. The project calls for 12 ships to be built in Australia-eight for the Royal Australian Navy and four for the Royal New Zealand Navy.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Australian of 3 November 1988 I discovered an added dimension to the project revealed in a confidential report to the New Zealand Cabinet by the New Zealand Prime Minister, Mr Lange. That report indicates that both Prime Minister Hawke and Defence Minister Beazley see a successful Anzac ship project as being central to a closer trans-Tasman relationship, with any suggestion of New Zealand opting out of the project as raising questions not only about its defence commitment and credibility but also about closer diplomatic and economic relations with Australia generally.

The House will be aware that the project has aroused a storm of criticism in New Zealand, from both peace groups and the Labour Party conference. New Zealand has always been a strong and valued ally of Australia, and should remain so, despite the Lange Government's disappointing attitude to the broader ANZUS arrangements previously in place. Therefore, it is important that Prime Minister Hawke make clear to Prime Minister Lange, once again, that Australia's intention to carry the Anzac ship project research costs, to allow delays in project payments and to provide a special deal on spare parts cannot be taken for granted ad infinitum.
To clarify the present situation, I will be placing on the Notice Paper the following question to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley):

Will the Minister confirm that New Zealand authorities visited Australia during the week commencing 31 October? If so, was this a routine project visit or are there serious doubts about New Zealand's commitment to the project? If the New Zealand commitment is questionable, can the Minister provide assurances that the project is viable for Australia on a unilateral basis? If the answer to the last part is yes, is the Minister satisfied that the present budgetary cost cap per ship will be sufficient to provide eight operational platforms for the Royal Australian Navy that will satisfy fully the naval force structure requirements set out in the Dibb report and in the resultant defence White Paper?

The New Zealand Government should be left in no doubt that if a country fails to meet its responsibilities, that failure brings substantive penalties. Any political ties that might exist between the two governments should take a back seat to the broader Australian national interest.

This country needs those replacement ships and New Zealand should be asked to put its money where its political mouth is before this essential project goes the way of many others-down the path of indecision, of wasted resource and towards a further loss of morale in what is already a Defence Force that is clearly bleeding to death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for giving me the opportunity to finish what I started. The methadone program to which I referred has been very effective in Holland where there has been a significant decrease in the last five years in the number of young people who are interested and, indeed, involved in using drugs. The program in Australia was focused upon yesterday in the Sunday program on Channel 9. Many of us who watched that report would have been interested to see that, according to the report, there are shortages in methadone in a number of States. As a result, there are queues of people who wish to be involved in the program but who are unable to get hold of methadone. As a result of that report, I made some inquires today in respect of Western Australia. It seems that the problem does not exist there but it is certainly a source of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the program does not solve the problem but it provides a drug addict with the opportunity to get some breathing space. It reduces the pressure to get a hit and to take part in the other nefarious activities that go along with it. Indeed, it provides some opportunity for a drug addict to normalise his lifestyle. In Holland the experience clearly has been that increasing numbers of people have voluntarily undertaken detoxification and drug rehabilitation as a result of such programs. Certainly, this is something about which we should be ever vigilant in Australia. Clearly, in those States where there is a problem with access to methadone it is necessary to look very closely at the availability of the program to make sure that people are not left waiting on the list. It is at our cost and a cost to our economy if large numbers of people who could be productive citizens are excluded from the program.

The problem of drug abuse is, as I have suggested, a vast one. There is a great deal of hypocrisy in our attitude to it. Drugs which are supposedly legal are available and yet they cause massive damage and problems within our community. I refer, of course, to alcohol and tobacco. These are drugs that we have to live with. But, increasingly, we are finding through education and prevention that there is an awareness of the problems associated with these drugs. Those drugs which are considered illegal are another problem.

It is important that those who are found guilty of illegal drug abuse should not suffer more from criminal proceedings than from the use of a drug itself. That is an attitude that we need to develop. Indeed, we need to look at this problem as a health problem rather than as a punitive criminal one. It is important that our education, treatment and enforcement be innovative and for radical new programs, such as the one I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, to be considered. Unless we are creative in our thinking, we will find this problem ever increasing and difficult to control.
